designated as provided herein, except in case of an emergency.
C. The operator of a bus shall enter a bus stop, bus stand or passenger loading zone on a public street in such
a manner that the bus when stopped to load or unload passengers or baggage shall be in a position with
the right front wheel of such vehicle not further than eighteen inches (18") from the curb and the bus
approximately parallel to the curb so as not to unduly impede the movement of other vehicular traffic.
D. The operator of a taxicab shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street at any place other than in a
taxicab stand so designated as provided herein. This provision shall not prevent the operator of a taxicab
from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the
purpose of and while actually engaged in the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers. (2001 Code
§ 75.34)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 164/395
75.35: RESTRICTED USE OF BUS AND TAXICAB STANDS:
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop, or other than a taxicab in a
taxicab stand, when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except
that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually
engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab
waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. (2001 Code § 75.35)
Title 9
GENERAL REGULATIONS
Chapter 90
ANIMALS
General Provisions
90.01: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or
requires a different meaning:
ANIMAL: Any horse, mule, donkey, pony, cow, sheep, goat, hog, dog, cat, rabbit, chicken, goose, duck, turkey,
peacock or other animal, fowl or reptile.
ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER: An employee of the city, hired by the city manager for the purpose of
controlling animals and enforcing this chapter, and impounding and destroying animals as prescribed by law.
ANIMAL ESTABLISHMENT: Any pet shop, grooming shop, animal auction, performing animal exhibition,
stable, coop, warren, kennel or other structure wherein animals are kept, except that this term shall not apply
to veterinary medical facilities, licensed research facilities or zoological parks.
ANIMAL SHELTER: A facility permitted and recognized by the city for the purpose of impounding and caring
for animals.
AT LARGE: Not under "physical restraint", as defined in this section, or not securely confined within the
owner's home.
DANGEROUS DOG OR POTENTIALLY DANGEROUS DOG: Any dog that:
A. Has inflicted any physical injury resulting in broken bones or lacerations requiring multiple sutures or
cosmetic surgery on a human being without provocation by the victim on public or private property; or
B. Has been previously found to be potentially dangerous, the owner having received written notice of the
finding by the Woodward animal control authority and the dog thereafter aggressively bites, attacks or
endangers the safety of humans; or
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 165/395
C. When unprovoked, has inflicted bites on a human either on public or private property; or
D. As otherwise defined in 4 Oklahoma Statutes section 44 et seq., and as amended.
HOUSEHOLD PET: A domesticated animal regularly kept as a pet within a house or enclosed yard, including
dogs, cats, hamsters, guinea pigs, caged birds or any animal used to assist handicapped persons, but shall
not include chickens, geese, turkeys, horses, cows, pigs or other livestock. Vietnamese potbellied pigs shall
not be considered household pets.
HUMANE MANNER: Care of an animal to include, but not limited to, adequate heat, shade, ventilation and
sanitary shelter, wholesome food and water, consistent with the normal requirements and feeding habits of the
animal size, species and breed.
KENNEL: An establishment, residence or other property wherein more than two (2) dogs or three (3) cats, or a
combination of dogs and cats not to exceed a total of three (3), are kept or where dogs and cats are kept for
the purposes of breeding, boarding, selling or training.
NEUTERED: Rendered permanently incapable of reproduction, whether used in reference to the male or
female of the species.
OWNER: Any person, firm or corporation owning, harboring or keeping an animal. All the occupants of any
premises on which a domesticated or tamed animal remains, or to which it customarily returns, for a period of
ten (10) days or more, shall jointly and severally be deemed to be harboring or keeping an animal.
PET SHOP: An establishment engaged in the business of buying, selling, breeding or raising of animals for
profitmaking purposes, whether or not business transactions are made on the premises.
PHYSICAL RESTRAINT: Secure confinement of an animal by fence, chain or leash. To qualify as secure
confinement under the terms of this chapter:
A. A fence must be at least two (2) times as tall as the height of the dog or other animal when standing on
its hind legs; or there must be an enclosed top or roof over the entire fenced area; or the fence must be
of sufficient height that the dog or other animal cannot escape; the bottom of the fence must be buried so
as to not allow the dog or other animal to dig or burrow to escape, or a floor must be attached.
B. A chain or cable must be attached to a tree, post or other stationary object which is strong enough to
hold the weight and force of the animal in question; the chain or cable must be of sufficient strength to
hold the dog or animal in question; the chain or cable must be attached to a collar, bridle or other
harness of sufficient strength to hold the animal; and the chain or cable must be of a length which will not
allow the animal to be within five feet (5') of a public street, alley, walkway, mailbox, or utility meter or
pole.
C. A leash must be no more than six feet (6') in length and must be of sufficient strength to hold the animal,
and must be attached to a collar, bridle or other harness which is of a sufficient strength to hold the
animal, and the leash must be under the immediate control of a person physically capable of restraining
the animal.
D. Physical restraint of a vicious, dangerous or potentially dangerous dog shall require the muzzling of the
dog in addition to the provisions in subsections B and C of this definition.
E. Animals in or on vehicles traveling or parked within the city must be securely confined within or to the
vehicle by means which conform to the above provisions.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 166/395
VICIOUS ANIMAL: An animal which has bitten or attempted to bite any person without due provocation, or
which attacks, growls or acts as if it intends to attack or bite, or bites a person or persons, when not unduly
provoked. The refusal of a postal carrier to deliver mail or parcels to an address because of the threat of an
animal attack shall be prima facie evidence that an animal is vicious.
WILD OR EXOTIC ANIMAL: Any of the following animals:
A. A lion, tiger, leopard, panther, cougar, bobcat, ocelot, cheetah, margay, mountain lion, lynx, jaguar,
jaguarundi, or any and all other felines (family Felidae), except the domestic cat (species Felis
domesticus);
B. A grizzly bear, black bear, or any and all other bears (family Ursidae);
C. A wolf, coyote, jackal, hyena, or any and all other canines (family Canidae), except the domestic dog
(species Canis familiaris) or the fox;
D. Any and all venomous reptiles (venomous members of the class Reptilia), including, without limitation,
Gila monsters (species Heloderma suspectum), beaded lizards (species Heloderma horridum), and
venomous snakes (venomous members of the suborder Serpentes);
E. Any anaconda (species Eunectes murinus);
F. Any and all crocodiles, caimans or alligators (family Crocodilia);
G. Gorillas, orangutans, baboons, macaques or chimpanzees; or any nonhuman primate;
H. Cassowaries (genus Casuarius); or
I. Any cross breed or hybrid of any two (2) animals defined as exotic wildlife in subsections A through H of
this definition. (2001 Code § 90.01; amd. Ord. 1519, 12-20-2010; 2012 Code)
Regulations
90.15: KEEPING OF CERTAIN ANIMALS PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS:
A. Permit Required: No person shall own, harbor or keep any animal, except a dog, cat or other household
pet, within the corporate limits of the city without a permit as provided in section 90.55 of this chapter.
B. Prohibited Animals; Exception:
1. Notwithstanding subsection A of this section, it shall be unlawful to own, or in any way possess, within
the corporate limits of the city:
a. Any warm blooded carnivorous or omnivorous, wild or exotic animal; (2001 Code § 90.15)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 167/395
b. Any animal having a poisonous or venomous bite; or (2001 Code § 90.15; amd. 2012 Code)
c. Any vicious or dangerous animal.
2. This subsection shall not apply to properly permitted exhibitions, animal shows and circuses.
C. Domesticated Farm And Ranch Animals: Notwithstanding subsection A of this section, domesticated farm
and ranch animals may be temporarily harbored or kept within the city as follows:
1. At Crystal Beach;
2. At the sale barn or stockyards;
3. For no more than seven (7) days for the purpose of participation in the annual Elks Rodeo And Parade,
annual American Legion Horseraces, or other horseraces to be conducted at Crystal Beach Park, fairs,
livestock shows or other exhibitions. (2001 Code § 90.15)
D. At Large Prohibited; Exception For Cats: Notwithstanding subsection A of this section, no person shall allow
an animal owned, harbored or kept by them to be at large; provided, however, cats may be at large unless
the cat or cats constitute a nuisance. Untagged cats shall be considered feral (wild) cats. (2001 Code
§ 90.15; amd. 2012 Code)
E. Kennels: Notwithstanding subsection A of this section, no person shall allow a concentration of animals
exceeding two (2) dogs or three (3) cats, or any combination thereof, which exceeds three (3) to be kept on
their property without a kennel permit. (2001 Code § 90.15)
90.16: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
A. All animals kept within the city limits shall be cared for in a humane manner and in such a manner as to not
create a nuisance.
B. No person shall intentionally, wilfully or maliciously beat, injure, maim or mutilate any animal, whether
belonging to himself or another, or fail to provide an animal with necessary food, drink and shelter.
C. Any animal control officer or police officer finding an animal so maltreated or abused shall cause the same
to be impounded. The animal shall be held until authorization to release the animal is received by the
municipal court. (2001 Code § 90.16)
90.17: ABANDONING ANIMALS:
A. No person shall knowingly abandon an animal that is owned, harbored or kept by him. (2001 Code § 90.17)
B. Any person desiring to cease owning, harboring or keeping a dog shall take the dog to the city animal
pound, giving custody of the dog to the animal control officer. The dog shall be subject to immediate
adoption or humanely destroyed, unless redeemed as provided in sections 90.39 through 90.41 of this
chapter. (2001 Code § 90.17; amd. 2012 Code)
C. Animals may be delivered to the animal shelter by their owners to be destroyed for humane reasons. (2001
Code § 90.17)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 168/395
90.18: POISONING ANIMALS:
No person shall wilfully poison any animal or knowingly expose poison so that the same may be taken by an
animal. (2001 Code § 90.18)
90.19: ENCOURAGING ANIMALS TO FIGHT:
No person shall instigate or encourage a fight between animals; or encourage one animal to attack, pursue or
annoy another animal; or keep a house, pit or other place used for fights between animals. (2001 Code
§ 90.19)
90.20: HUNTING ANIMALS, BIRDS AND WILD FOWL:
No person shall trap, hunt, shoot or molest in any manner, any animal, bird or wild fowl, or the nests thereof,
except as provided herein. (2001 Code § 90.20)
90.21: VICIOUS OR DANGEROUS ANIMALS:
Any person may kill a vicious or dangerous animal in his self-defense, or in defense of another, or in defense
of his personal property, or in defense of an animal belonging to him. (2001 Code § 90.21)
90.22: ANIMAL ESTABLISHMENT REGULATIONS:
A. Permit Required: No person shall operate, build, use or otherwise possess an animal establishment without
first obtaining a permit as provided in section 90.55 of this chapter.
B. Regulations:
1. No animal establishment shall be maintained closer than three hundred feet (300') to any hotel,
restaurant, boarding house, retail food store or building used for educational, religious or hospital
purposes; except that a grooming shop, temporary animal boarding establishment may be maintained
within three hundred feet (300'), but no closer than one hundred fifty feet (150') to any hotel, restaurant,
boarding house, retail food store or building used for educational, religious or hospital purposes so long
as the animals do not remain on the premises during the overnight period defined herein as being from
eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. to six o'clock (6:00) A.M.
2. No animal establishment shall be maintained closer than forty feet (40') to any residence other than that
occupied by the owner of the premises upon which the animal is owned, harbored or kept.
3. Every animal establishment wherein an animal is owned, harbored or kept shall be maintained in a clean
and sanitary condition, devoid of rodents and vermin, and free of objectionable odors.
4. Every animal establishment shall be provided with a watertight and flytight receptacle for manure, of
such size as to hold all accumulations of manure. Such receptacle shall be emptied sufficiently often and
in such a manner as to prevent it from becoming a nuisance and shall be kept covered at all times,
except while opened during the deposit or removal of manure or refuse. No manure shall be allowed to
accumulate on such premises except in such receptacle. Manure shall be hauled outside the city in a
manner which does not jeopardize the public health, or else shall be spread evenly upon the ground and
turned under immediately.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 169/395
C. Pasturing, Staking Or Confining An Animal: No person shall pasture, stake or confine any animal on any
property within the city without the written consent of the owner of such property.
D. Establishments To Comply With Building Code: Any animal establishment erected or used within the city
must comply with the building code for buildings, sheds or structures as such is in effect within the city.
E. Animal Control Officer To Inspect: The animal control officer, upon complaint of any person or upon his own
initiative, may inspect any stable, kennel, coop, building or other establishment wherein animals are being
owned, harbored or kept. He may issue any reasonable order necessary to cause such animal to be
owned, harbored and kept as provided in this chapter and in such a manner as to not constitute a
nuisance.
F. Turning Animals At Large Prohibited: No person shall open any enclosure in which any animal is confined
so as to turn such animal at large, or to release any animal from a leash or chain so as to turn such animal
at large, or to turn an animal at large in any other manner. (2001 Code § 90.22)
Vaccination Requirements; Impoundment
90.35: VACCINATION REQUIRED:
A. No person shall own, keep, or harbor any dog or cat over four (4) months of age within the city unless the
dog or cat is vaccinated against rabies. The provisions of this section do not apply to animals owned by a
licensed research facility or held in veterinary facility, or government operated or licensed animal shelter.
B. All dogs or cats shall be vaccinated against rabies at least annually by a licensed veterinarian, in
accordance with the latest "Compendium Of Animal Rabies Vaccines And Recommendations For
Immunization", published by the National Association Of State Public Health Veterinarians.
C. A certificate of vaccination shall be issued to the owner of each animal vaccinated on a form recommended
by the compendium. Each owner shall also receive a durable vaccination tag indicating the year in which it
was issued, which tag shall be attached to a collar worn by the animal. (2001 Code § 90.35)
90.36: IMPOUNDMENT OF UNTAGGED OR UNVACCINATED ANIMALS:
A. Any dog or cat not wearing a rabies tag as set forth in section 90.35 of this chapter shall be deemed to be
capable of carrying or transmitting rabies.
B. Any dog or cat capable of carrying or transmitting rabies and is at large, or which has bitten a person or is
suspected of being rabid, shall be impounded for a period of ten (10) days, unless the owner of the animal
can prove the animal has been vaccinated as required by subsection A of this section. (2001 Code
§ 90.36)
90.37: DESTRUCTION OF RABID ANIMALS:
An animal determined to be rabid shall be immediately destroyed. If an animal which has bitten a person
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 170/395
cannot be captured, the animal may be immediately destroyed so that a laboratory confirmation may be made.
An animal bitten by a rabid animal shall be either destroyed immediately or impounded at the cost to the owner
of two dollars ($2.00) per day for a period of at least six (6) months, at the option of the owner of the bitten
animal. (2001 Code § 90.37)
90.38: IMPOUNDMENT PROCEDURES:
A. Any animal, with the exception of household pets, found at large within the city may be immediately taken or
placed into the custody of the city and taken to the city pound and impounded, and be kept therein for a
period of at least ninety six (96) hours, and then humanely destroyed, unless sooner redeemed as provided
for herein. (2001 Code § 90.38; amd. 2012 Code)
B. An animal control officer may impound any dog believed to be vicious or dangerous. Upon impoundment,
the animal's owner may make application to the municipal court clerk's office for release of the dog. Such
application must be made within ninety six (96) hours of the impoundment or the animal may be humanely
destroyed by the city. If application is made, the animal shall be held until the municipal court renders a
decision determining that the animal is not vicious or dangerous, or that the owner has complied with the
requirements of 4 Oklahoma Statutes section 44 et seq. The owner shall pay a holding fee of five dollars
($5.00) per day and an impoundment fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00), which fees are nonrefundable and shall
be paid with the application.
C. Any animal not covered by a permit as required by this chapter shall be impounded. (2001 Code § 90.38)
90.39: REDEMPTION:
A. The owner may redeem the animal within seventy two (72) hours after its impoundment by presenting proof
of ownership; proof of vaccination as provided for in this chapter; and the receipt of the payment of
impoundment fees as set forth in this chapter. (2001 Code § 90.39; amd. 2012 Code)
B. The owner or other person may redeem the animal after seventy two (72) hours and before ninety six (96)
hours of impoundment by presenting proof of vaccination as provided for in this chapter, or have the animal
vaccinated against rabies while impounded, and the receipt for the payment of impoundment fees set forth
in this chapter. (2001 Code § 90.39)
90.40: FEES:
A. Fees for impounding an animal shall be paid upon redemption and shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00), plus five
dollars ($5.00) per day for each day the animal is impounded; provided, however, if the same animal has
been impounded more than once, the impoundment and daily fees for each subsequent impoundment shall
double. For example, fees for the second impoundment would be a thirty dollar ($30.00) fee, plus ten
dollars ($10.00) per day. The third would be sixty dollars ($60.00), plus twenty dollars ($20.00) per day.
B. Any person redeeming an impounded animal shall pay the required fees to the city clerk and present his
receipt therefor and proof of vaccination to the animal control officer. (2001 Code § 90.40)
90.41: ADOPTION; FEE:
Any animal may be adopted from the city pound or a permitted animal shelter after seventy two (72) hours. An
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 171/395
adoption fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be assessed at the time of the adoption. Vaccination fees, licensing
and veterinary costs for sterilization shall be assessed above and beyond the adoption fee. A refundable ten
dollar ($10.00) sterilization fee will be assessed for unaltered animals. Proof of sterilization will be required for
refund of the sterilization fee. (2001 Code § 90.41; amd. 2012 Code)
90.42: DISPOSITION OF ANIMALS:
All animals not redeemed or adopted within ninety six (96) hours shall become the property of the city and may
be humanely destroyed or delivered to any nonprofit animal organization or shelter; provided, that the animals
shall not be used for experimental purposes and shall be the sole responsibility of the organization; and also
provided, that the animal control officer or his agent shall make a reasonable effort to notify any person
identified on the collar of an animal prior to the disposition of that animal. (2001 Code § 90.42)
90.43: INTERFERENCE PROHIBITED:
No person shall interfere with, hinder or molest any agent of the animal control authority in the performance of
any duty as herein provided. (2001 Code § 90.43)
Administration And Enforcement
90.55: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Conditions: All permits for animals and animal establishments shall be issued by the city clerk upon
acceptance of application and verification of the signatures. Application forms must be obtained from the
city clerk's office and shall state the number and types of animals which are to be kept on the premises.
B. Application For Permit: All applications shall be completed and signed by owner of the household, and shall
contain the signatures of one hundred percent (100%) of the owners of all adjacent properties, and at least
fifty one percent (51%) of the owners of all properties within three hundred feet (300') of the borders of the
property on which the animal establishment shall be kept; provided, however, if such animal is a "vicious
animal" or "dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog", as defined in section 90.01 of this chapter, the
application must contain the signatures of one hundred percent (100%) of all property owners within three
hundred feet (300') of the boundaries of such property.
C. Revocation Based On Adjoining Landowner Objections: All permits are revocable upon the application or
petition of at least fifty one percent (51%) of the adjoining landowners or owners of property within three
hundred feet (300').
D. Term; Renewal: All permits are valid for one calendar year. Renewal of the permit may be granted only as
set forth below. All applications and permits are valid only for the animal or animal establishment listed
thereon. Separate applications and permits must be made for additional animals acquired while a permit is
in existence.
E. Fees: The fees for permits are as follows:
1. The fee for permits for an animal establishment, kennel or pet shop, other than those provided in
subsection E2 of this section, is fifty dollars ($50.00) and may be renewed yearly for ten dollars ($10.00),
provided no complaints regarding such animal or animal establishment, kennel or pet shop, have been
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 172/395
filed with the city clerk. If the city clerk has received a written complaint regarding such animal or
occupant of a property situated within three hundred feet (300'), the owner or operator thereof must file a
new application and submit a fifty dollar ($50.00) fee.
2. The fee for any permit involving a vicious animal or dangerous or potentially dangerous dog is seventy
five dollars ($75.00) per year, with renewal of such permit only upon completion of a new application and
payment of the seventy five dollar ($75.00) fee.
F. Nonassignable, Nontransferable: Each permit is nonassignable and nontransferable. (2001 Code § 90.55)
90.56: EXCEPTIONS:
Permits are not required for:
A. Facilities maintained by a veterinarian for the temporary housing of animals treated in his practice;
B. Animal control shelters maintained by the city;
C. Buildings and stables maintained at Crystal Beach Park;
D. Buildings and stables for animals maintained at the sale barns or stockyards for the purpose of auction
and sale of livestock;
E. Animals located within the city limits for no more than seven (7) days for the purpose of participation in
the annual Elks Rodeo And Parade, annual American Legion Horseraces, or other horseraces to be
conducted at Crystal Beach Park, fairs, livestock shows or other exhibitions;
F. Animal establishments operated and maintained on a minimum of five (5) acres; provided, however, the
establishments must comply with building codes and zoning ordinances;
G. Single litters of puppies and kittens under the age of twelve (12) weeks; or
H. Animals located at the agricultural barn at the Woodward High School. (2001 Code § 90.56)
90.57: COMPLIANCE WITH ZONING:
No permit may be granted in violation of the zoning ordinance. (2001 Code § 90.57)
90.58: REVOCATION, EXPIRATION:
All persons required by this chapter to have a permit must promptly remove all animals or animal
establishments upon the expiration, revocation or nonexistence of the permit. The animals shall be subject to
impoundment, and the establishments shall be subject to condemnation no sooner than fifteen (15) days from
the date of the expiration or revocation of the permit or the city discovery of the nonexistence of the permit.
(2001 Code § 90.58)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 173/395
90.59: AUTHORITY OF ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER TO ENFORCE:
Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit the police or animal control officers from taking such steps as are
necessary to capture noxious, nondomesticated animals; to prevent concentration of birds in such numbers as
may constitute a nuisance; or to enforce this chapter. (2001 Code § 90.59)
90.99: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter or fails to comply therewith or with any of the
requirements thereof, shall be guilty of an offense against the people of the city and, upon conviction, shall be
punished by a fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), plus court costs. Each day upon which
a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. Each animal involved in a violation shall be deemed
a separate offense. (2001 Code § 90.99)
Chapter 91
FAIR HOUSING
91.01: DISCRIMINATION IN SALE OR RENTAL OF HOUSING UNLAWFUL:
It shall be unlawful:
A. To refuse to sell or rent after the making of a bona fide offer, or to refuse to negotiate for the sale or rental
of, or otherwise make unavailable or deny, a dwelling to any person because of race, color, religion,
gender, national origin, familial status or handicap.
B. To discriminate against any person in the terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental of a dwelling, or in
the provision of services or facilities in connection therewith, because of race, color, religion, gender,
national origin, familial status or handicap.
C. To make, print or publish, or cause to be made, printed or published, any notice, statement or
advertisement, with respect to the sale or rental of a dwelling that indicates any preference, limitation, or
discrimination based on race, color, religion, gender, national origin, familial status or handicap, or an
intention to make any such preference, limitation or discrimination.
D. To represent to any person because of race, color, religion, gender, national origin, familial status or
handicap that any dwelling is not available for inspection, sale or rental when such dwelling is in fact so
available.
E. For profit, to induce or attempt to induce any person to sell or rent any dwelling by representations
regarding the entry or prospective entry into the neighborhood of a person or persons of a particular race,
color, religion, gender, national origin, familial status or handicap. (2001 Code § 91.01; amd. 2012 Code)
91.02: EXEMPTIONS:
Nothing in section 91.01 of this chapter shall apply:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 174/395
A. 1. To any single-family house sold or rented by an owner, provided:
a. The owner does not own any interest in, nor is there owned or reserved on his behalf, under any
express or voluntary agreement, title to or any right to all or a portion of the proceeds from the sale or
rental of more than three (3) single-family houses at any one time.
b. In the case of the sale of the single-family house by an owner not residing in the house at the time of
the sale, or who was not the most recent resident of the house prior to the sale, the exemption granted
by this section shall apply only with respect to one sale within any twenty four (24) month period.
c. The single-family house is sold or rented without the use in any manner of the sales, facilities or
services of a real estate broker, agent, salesperson or person in the business of selling or renting
houses.
d. The single-family house is sold or rented without the publication, posting or mailing, after notice, of any
advertisement or written notice in violation of subsection 91.01C of this chapter.
2. Nothing in this provision shall prohibit the use of attorneys, escrow agents, abstractors, title companies
and other such professional assistance as necessary to perfect or transfer the title.
B. To rooms or units in dwellings containing living quarters occupied or intended to be occupied by no more
than four (4) families living independently of each other, if the owner actually maintains and occupies one of
such living quarters as his residence. (2001 Code § 91.02)
C. To prohibit a religious organization, association or society, or any nonprofit institution or organization
operated, supervised or controlled by or in conjunction with a religious organization, association or society,
from limiting the sale, rental or occupancy of dwellings which it owns or operates for other than a
commercial purpose to persons of the same religion, or from giving preference to such persons, unless
membership in such religion is restricted on account of race, color, gender, national origin, familial status or
handicap. (2001 Code § 91.02; amd. 2012 Code)
D. To prohibit a private club not in fact open to the public, which as an incident to its primary purpose or
purposes provides lodgings which it owns or operates for other than commercial purposes, from limiting the
rental or occupancy of the lodgings to its members or from giving preference to its members. (2001 Code
§ 91.02)
91.03: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT BY HOUSING BOARD OF APPEALS:
The authority and responsibility for administering this chapter shall be in the housing board of appeals,
hereafter referred to as the board, organized under section 152.82 of this code. (2001 Code § 91.03)
91.04: GRIEVANCE PROCEDURE:
A. Written Complaint: Any person aggrieved by a discriminatory housing practice prohibited by this chapter
may file with the board a written complaint, subscribed under oath, setting forth the name and address of
the person alleged to have violated the provisions of this chapter, and shall further set forth the particulars
of the violation, and shall further set forth any additional information required by the board.
B. Time Limit For Filing: A complaint under subsection A of this section must be filed within one hundred eighty
(180) days after the alleged discriminatory housing practice occurred, or the same is forever barred.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 175/395
C. Investigation: The board shall investigate each properly filed complaint, and shall attempt an adjustment of
the complaint by informal methods of conference, conciliation and persuasion.
D. Dismissal: If the board determines that a complaint is not well founded, it shall dismiss the complaint and
notify the complainant of the dismissal.
E. Hearing: If informal methods do not result in compliance with this chapter, the board shall cause to be
issued and served in the name of the city a written notice, together with a copy of the complaint, requiring
the person named in the complaint, hereinafter referred to as respondent, to answer the complaint at a
hearing before the board at a time and place to be specified in the notice.
F. Notice: A copy of the written notice shall be mailed to the complainant at his or her most current business or
residence address.
G. Conduct Of Hearing: After the issuance of notice, the board shall conduct a hearing. The complainant and
respondent may be present, and may be represented by counsel. The testimony at the hearing shall be
under oath, and shall be transcribed at the request of either party, or at the direction of the board. The
costs of such transcription shall be borne by the person requesting the same. The board shall determine all
other rules and regulations for conducting the hearing.
H. No Findings Of Discrimination; Dismissal: If the board, upon hearing, finds that the respondent has not
engaged in any discriminatory practice, it shall state its findings, and shall dismiss the complaint.
I. Findings Of Discrimination: If the board, upon hearing, finds that the respondent has engaged in any
discriminatory practice, it shall certify its findings to the city attorney, who shall thereupon instigate the
necessary proceedings in the municipal court. (2001 Code § 91.04)
91.99: PENALTY:
It shall be unlawful, and constitute an offense for any person, firm or corporation to discriminate in sale or
rental of housing as set forth in section 91.01 of this chapter, and any person found guilty of violating section
91.01 of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of an offense and subject to a fine of not more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00). Each day upon which a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. (2001 Code
§ 91.99)
Chapter 92
FIRE PREVENTION
General Provisions
92.01: FIRE CHIEF; APPOINTMENT AND DUTIES:
A. Appointment; Assistants: There shall be a fire chief, who shall be appointed by the city manager for an
indefinite term and who shall be removable by the city manager. The city manager may also appoint
assistant fire chiefs, who shall serve indefinite terms and who shall be removable by the city manager.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 176/395
Whenever any law or ordinance refers to the fire chief it shall be deemed to mean the fire chief or assistant
fire chiefs set forth in this section.
B. Powers And Duties: The fire chief shall have all the powers, duties and functions as set forth within this
chapter, and shall conduct all inspections and issue all permits and notices as hereinafter required.
C. Authority To Enter Premises: The fire chief is hereby vested with full authority to enter any premises in the
discharge of his duties and to pass upon and decide any questions arising under the provisions of this
chapter.
D. Interference Prohibited: No person shall interfere with the fire chief in the discharge of his duties. (2001
Code § 92.01)
92.02: ESTABLISHMENT OF FIRE LIMITS:
The limits referred to in the international fire code, 2009 edition, in which the storage of explosives,
ammunition and blasting agents is prohibited shall be set at the discretion and determination of the fire chief,
as set forth in section 92.01 of this chapter. (2001 Code § 92.02; amd. 2012 Code)
Adoption Of Codes
92.15: INTERNATIONAL FIRE CODE ADOPTED:
A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of code enforcement of the city, being
marked and designated as international fire code, 2015 edition, as published, amended and modified by the
International Code Council is hereby adopted as the fire code for the city for the control of buildings and
structures as herein provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms
of said international fire code are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this
section, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 92.16 of this
chapter. (Ord. 1644, 11-21-2016)
92.16: ADDITIONS, INSERTIONS AND CHANGES:
The following sections of the international fire code, as set forth in section 92.15 of this chapter, are hereby
revised as follows:
Section 101.1 Insert: city of Woodward.
Section 109.4 Insert: Misdemeanor, $100.00 and no imprisonment.
Section 111.4 Insert: $20.00 and $100.00 per offense, per day.
(Ord. 1644, 11-21-2016)
92.17: NFPA LIFE SAFETY CODE ADOPTED:
A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of code enforcement of the city, being
marked and designated as the NFPA 101 life safety code, 2015 edition, as published by the National Fire
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 177/395
Protection Association (NFPA), is hereby adopted as the life safety code for the city for the purpose of
prescribing regulations for safety to life from fire and like emergencies in buildings and structures, is hereby
known as the life safety code of the city and is hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully
set out in this section, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed by this section.
(Ord. 1644, 11-21-2016)
General Regulations
92.30: INFLAMMABLE LIQUIDS:
A. Liquefied petroleum gas cannot be stored within the city except upon application to the fire chief, who, upon
hearing, determines that the proposed storage will not constitute a hazard to the public or property and
thereupon issues a permit authorizing the storage.
B. No person, firm or corporation shall vend any inflammable liquid, such as gasoline, motor fuel or other
derivative of petroleum, or any of its byproducts, from any automatic vendor or vending machine whereby a
coin is deposited by the purchaser and such liquids are automatically dispensed, or to set up or cause to
be set up such automatic vending machine within the city. (2001 Code § 92.30)
92.31: OPEN BURNING; EXCEPTIONS:
A. Prohibition: No person shall cause, suffer, allow or permit open burning of refuse or other combustible
materials within the city.
B. Exceptions: The prohibitions of this section shall not apply to open burning under the following
circumstances:
1. Upon written application to the fire chief and upon a permit being issued authorizing open burning:
a. For the instruction and training of public and industrial firefighting personnel;
b. For the elimination of fire hazards which cannot be abated by any other means;
c. For the removal of dangerous and hazardous material where there is no other practical or lawful
method of disposal; and
d. For recreational and ceremonial occasions, or for outdoor commercial preparation of food.
2. Open burning for outdoor noncommercial preparation of food. (2001 Code § 92.31)
92.32: GRASS AND WEED ACCUMULATION:
No person owning real property or in possession of real property as a tenant or otherwise shall allow
excessive grass or weeds to accumulate on the property by failure to mow or otherwise control and dispose of
the same, thus constituting a fire, safety or health hazard on the premises. (2001 Code § 92.32)
92.33: RUBBISH, JUNK OR DEBRIS ACCUMULATION:
No person owning real property or in possession of real property as a tenant or otherwise shall allow
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 178/395
excessive brush, lumber, paper materials, metals, or other rubbish, junk or debris to accumulate on the
property, thus constituting a fire, safety or health hazard on the premises. (2001 Code § 92.33)
Removal Of Dangerous And Detrimental Conditions
92.45: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply, unless the context clearly indicates or
requires a different meaning:
CLEANING: The removal of trash from property.
OWNER: The owner of record as shown by the most current tax rolls of the county treasurer.
TRASH: Any refuse, litter, ashes, leaves, debris, paper, combustible materials, rubbish, offal, or waste, or
matter of any kind or form which is uncared for, discarded or abandoned.
WEED: A. Includes, but is not limited to, poison ivy, poison oak or poison sumac and all vegetation at any state
of maturity which:
1. Exceeds twelve inches (12") in height, except healthy trees, shrubs or produce for human
consumption grown in a tended and cultivated garden, unless such trees and shrubbery by their
density or location constitute a detriment to the health, benefit and welfare of the public and community
or a hazard to traffic or create a fire hazard to the property or otherwise interfere with the mowing of
said weeds;
2. Regardless of height, harbors, conceals or invites deposits or accumulation of refuse or trash;
3. Harbors rodents or vermin;
4. Gives off unpleasant or noxious odors;
5. Constitutes a fire or traffic hazard; or
6. Is dead or diseased.
B. The term "weed" shall not include tended crops on land zoned for agricultural use which are planted
more than one hundred fifty feet (150') from a parcel zoned for other than agricultural use. (2001 Code
§ 92.45)
92.46: AUTHORITY OF FIRE CHIEF; DETERMINATION:
A. The fire chief is authorized to determine whether the condition of property within the city limits constitutes a
detriment or hazard, and whether the public and the property would be benefited by the removal of such
conditions and that the property should be cleaned or mowed in accordance with the procedures set out in
subsection B of this section and sections 92.47 through 92.52 of this chapter.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 179/395
B. Upon receipt of information, complaint or visual inspection, the fire chief may determine whether property
within the city must be cleaned or mowed; provided, such determination may be made pursuant to a
hearing or through visual inspection. (2001 Code § 92.46)
92.47: WRITTEN NOTICE REQUIREMENTS:
A. Notice Required: Upon determination that the property must be cleaned or mowed, the fire chief shall cause
written notice to the owner of the property to be sent through certified mail, return receipt requested, to the
owner of the property at the address shown by the current year's county tax rolls. The fire chief may also
cause the notice to be posted on the property or published in a newspaper of general circulation. If the
owner is not identified or fails to receive the notice, notice must be published or posted at least ten (10)
days prior to the cleaning or mowing.
B. Content Of Notice: The notice must give the property owner at least ten (10) days to clean the property of
trash or to mow the weeds, as appropriate. The notice shall state that unless the work is performed within
ten (10) days from the date of the notice, the work shall be done by the municipality and that a notice of lien
shall be filed with the county clerk for the costs due and owed the municipality. The notice shall also state
that the city may clean or mow the property, as needed, within the next six (6) months without further prior
notice to the owner, with such additional costs being added to the lien after notice of the costs to the
property owner and the thirty (30) day payment period. The property owner should be informed that he may
appeal the costs of any further cleaning or mowing by filing an appeal within ten (10) days after subsequent
notice of additional costs. The notice may give the location of the property by street address and/or legal
description. (2001 Code § 92.47)
92.48: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
Upon a finding that the condition of the property constitutes a detriment or hazard, and that the public and the
property would benefit from the removal of the conditions, the agents of the municipality are granted the right
of entry on the property for the removal of trash, mowing of weeds or grass, and performance of the necessary
duties as a governmental function of the municipality. Immediately following the cleaning or mowing of the
property, the city clerk shall file a notice of lien with the county clerk describing the property and the work
performed by the municipality, and stating that the municipality claims a lien on the property for the cleaning or
mowing costs. (2001 Code § 92.48)
92.49: COSTS TO OWNERS:
The city commission shall determine the actual cost of such cleaning and mowing and any other expenses as
may be necessary in connection therewith, including the cost of notice and mailing. The city clerk shall forward
by mail to the property owner specified in subsection 92.47A of this chapter, a statement of the actual cost and
demanding payment. If the cleaning and mowing are done by the municipality, the cost to the property owner
for the cleaning and mowing shall not exceed the actual cost of the labor, maintenance and equipment
required. If the cleaning and mowing are done on a private contract basis, the contract shall be awarded to the
lowest and best bidder. (2001 Code § 92.49)
92.50: FAILURE TO PAY CONSTITUTES A LIEN:
If payment is not made within thirty (30) days from the date of the mailing of the statement, the city clerk shall
forward a certified statement of the amount of the cost to the Woodward county treasurer and the same shall
be levied on the property and collected by the county treasurer as other taxes authorized by law. Until fully
paid, the cost and the interest thereon shall be the personal obligation of the property owner from and after the
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 180/395
date the cost is certified to the county treasurer. In addition, the cost and the interest thereon shall be a lien
against the property from the date the cost is certified to the county treasurer, coequal with the lien of ad
valorem taxes and all other taxes and special assessments and prior and superior to all other titles and liens
against the property. The lien shall continue until the cost shall be fully paid. Upon receiving payment, if any,
the municipal clerk shall forward to the county treasurer a notice of such payment and directing discharge of
the lien. (2001 Code § 92.50)
92.51: APPEAL:
The property owner, within the ten (10) day period after the administrative decision by the fire chief, may
request an appeal of the fire chief's determination before the city commission by filing written notice with the
city clerk. Any appeal shall be heard on or before the next regularly scheduled commission meeting. (2001
Code § 92.51)
92.52: CONSENT OF OWNER TO AUTHORIZE REMOVAL:
Nothing in this subchapter shall prevent the property owner from submitting written consent to the city
authorizing the cleaning or mowing by the city, with the assessment to the property owner of costs incurred by
the city. (2001 Code § 92.52)
Unsafe Structures Or Buildings
92.65: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or
requires a different meaning:
BOARDING AND SECURING OR BOARDED AND SECURED: The closing, boarding or locking of any or all
exterior openings so as to prevent entry into the structure.
DILAPIDATED BUILDING: A structure which, through neglect or injury, lacks necessary repairs or otherwise is
in a state of decay or partial ruin to such an extent that the structure is a hazard to the health, safety or welfare
of the general public.
OWNER: The owner of record as shown by the most current tax rolls of the county treasurer.
UNSECURED BUILDING: Any structure which is not occupied by a legal or equitable owner thereof, or by a
lessee of a legal or equitable owner, and into which there are one or more unsecured openings such as broken
windows, unlocked windows, broken doors, unlocked doors, holes in exterior walls, holes in the roof, broken
basement or cellar hatchways, unlocked basement or cellar hatchways or other similar unsecured openings
which would facilitate an unauthorized entry into the structure. (2001 Code § 92.65)
92.66: AUTHORITY OF FIRE CHIEF; DETERMINATION:
A. The fire chief may cause dilapidated structures or buildings to be torn down and structures or buildings to
be boarded and secured according to the provisions of this subchapter.
B. Upon receipt of information, complaint or visual inspection, the fire chief may determine whether property
within the city contains a structure or building which is detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of the
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 181/395
public, and whether the structure or building should be removed or boarded and secured. (2001 Code
§ 92.66)
92.67: WRITTEN NOTICE REQUIREMENTS:
A. Notice Required: Upon the determination of the fire chief that a structure or building should be removed or
boarded and secured, the fire chief shall cause written notice to be mailed to the owner of the property at
the address shown by the current year's county tax rolls. Written notice shall also be mailed to any
mortgage holder as shown by the records in the office of the Woodward County clerk, such notice shall be
sent to the last known address of the mortgagee. For all such mailings, the fire chief shall obtain a receipt
of mailing from the postal service showing the date of mailing and the name and address of the owner or
mortgagee. Notice may be posted or published at least ten (10) days prior to the city action in the event the
owner and/or a mortgage holder cannot be located.
B. Content Of Notice: Notice under this section to the property owner and mortgagee shall state that for all
work done by the municipality, a notice of lien shall be filed with the county clerk for the costs due and
owed the municipality, to be collected as are authorized by law or other civil remedy as provided by law.
(2001 Code § 92.67)
92.68: HEARING AND APPEAL PROCEDURES:
A. Hearing: If a structure or building is to be removed, the notice specified in section 92.67 of this chapter shall
give the property owner and mortgagee at least ten (10) days' notice of a hearing before the city
commission. The notice shall state the date of the hearing and the lien procedures and other remedies set
forth below.
B. Appeal: If the boarding and securing of a structure or building is sought, either as a sole remedy or in
conjunction with the removal of the structure or building, the notice shall give the property owner ten (10)
days to board and secure the property himself or to submit a written request for an appeal before the city
commission. The appeal shall be filed with the city clerk within ten (10) days from the date of the notice.
(2001 Code § 92.68)
92.69: REMOVING AND SECURING STRUCTURES AND BUILDINGS; PROCEDURES:
Pursuant to a determination that the condition of the property constitutes a detriment or a hazard and that the
property would be benefited by the removal of such conditions, the commission may cause the dilapidated
building to be torn down and removed. The commission shall fix reasonable dates for the commencement and
completion of the work. Pursuant to the fire chief's determination that a building or structure should be boarded
and secured, the fire chief may cause the work to be performed after notice as provided in this subchapter.
The city clerk shall immediately file a notice of dilapidation and lien with the Woodward County clerk describing
the property, the findings of the fire chief or the commission, and stating that the municipality claims a lien on
the property for the costs of the work and that the costs are the personal obligation of the property owner from
and after the date of filing of the notice. The agents of the municipality are granted the right of entry on the
property for the performance of the necessary duties as a governmental function of the municipality if the work
is not performed by the property owner within dates fixed by the commission. In the event it is necessary for
the property owner to obtain a building permit or demolition permit pursuant to this code, the time allotted for
the commencement and completion of the work provided for in the permit shall not be construed to extend the
time fixed by the commission pursuant to this section. (2001 Code § 92.69)
92.70: COSTS TO OWNERS:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 182/395
The commission shall determine the actual cost of work and any other expenses that may be necessary in
conjunction with the work, including the cost of notice and mailing. The city clerk shall forward a statement of
the actual cost attributable to the work and a demand for payment of such costs, by certified mail, return
receipt required, to the property owner and any mortgage holder, at the addresses provided for in section
92.67 of this chapter. If a municipality performs work, the cost to the property owner shall not exceed the
actual cost of the labor, maintenance and equipment required. If the work is done on a private contract basis,
the contract shall be awarded to the lowest and best bidder. (2001 Code § 92.70)
92.71: CITY NOT LIABLE:
The officers, employees or agents of the municipality shall not be liable for any damages or loss of property
caused by the removal of dilapidated buildings performed pursuant to the provisions of this subchapter or as
otherwise prescribed by law. (2001 Code § 92.71)
92.72: CONSENT OF OWNER TO AUTHORIZE REQUIRED WORK:
Nothing in this subchapter shall prevent a property owner from submitting written consent to the city
authorizing work pursuant to this subchapter, with the assessment to the property owner for costs incurred by
the city. (2001 Code § 92.72)
92.73: CITY POWER TO ABATE:
Nothing in this subchapter shall prevent or prohibit the city from abating a nuisance or otherwise exercising its
police power in protecting the health, safety and welfare of the general public. (2001 Code § 92.73)
92.99: PENALTY:
A. Fines: Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or fails to
comply therewith or with any of the requirements thereof, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction,
shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day upon which a
violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense.
B. Actions In State Courts: No penalty imposed by and pursuant to this chapter shall interfere with the right of
the city or the public also to apply to the proper courts of the state for a mandamus, an injunction, or other
appropriate action against a person who violates or is about to violate any provision of this chapter.
C. Penalties Cumulative: The penalties provided by this section shall be cumulative and not exclusive. (2001
Code § 92.99)
Chapter 93
MUNICIPAL AIRPORT
93.01: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 183/395
requires a different meaning:
AIR NAVIGATION FACILITY OR FACILITY: Any facility other than one owned and operated by United States
Of America used in, available for use in, or designed for use in, aid of air navigation, including any structures,
mechanisms, lights, beacons, markers, communicating systems or other instrumentalities, or devices used or
useful as an aid, or constituting an advantage or convenience, to the safe take off, navigation and landing of
aircraft, or the safe and efficient operation or maintenance of an airport, and any combination of any or all of
such facilities.
AIRPORT: Any area of land or water designated, set aside, used, or intended for use, for the landing and take
off of aircraft, and any appurtenant areas designated, set aside, used, or intended for use, for airport buildings
or other airport facilities, rights of way, or approach zones, together with all airport buildings and facilities
located thereon.
AUTHORITY: The Woodward Municipal Airport authority as created by this chapter. (2001 Code § 93.01)
93.02: CREATION OF MUNICIPAL AIRPORT AUTHORITY:
A. There is hereby created a municipal airport authority as authorized and permitted by the municipal airports
act, 3 Oklahoma Statutes section 65.1 et seq., which shall be known and is hereby designated as the
Woodward Municipal Airport authority of the city of Woodward, state of Oklahoma.
B. Nothing found within this chapter is intended to limit, restrict or otherwise deter the city, as a municipal
corporation, from providing assistance, equipment or services in times of need or upon exigent
circumstances when requested by the authority in furtherance of a total spirit of cooperation for safe and
efficient air transportation. (2001 Code § 93.02)
93.03: MEMBERSHIP; COMPOSITION; TERMS:
A. Number; Appointment; Qualifications: The authority shall consist of seven (7) voting members who shall
serve by appointment of the city commission. Every member of the authority shall be a qualified voter of
the county from and after the time of their appointment. At least three (3) members shall have personal
knowledge concerning aircraft and airport operations.
B. Ex Officio Members: The president of the Woodward chamber of commerce, and the city manager and the
city attorney shall serve and be a part of the authority as nonvoting ex officio members. The president shall
assist in efforts for furthering development and promotion of air transportation for the people of the city. The
city manager shall assist in coordinating the various administrative matters which shall arise between the
authority, the city commission, and the regular administrative departments of the municipality. (2001 Code
§ 93.03; amd. Ord. 1548, 1-23-2012)
C. Terms; Compensation: The term of each member shall begin on January 1 of each year. All members of the
authority shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years or until their qualified successors are duly
appointed. Three (3) members of the authority shall initially be appointed for a term of one year. Two (2)
members of the authority shall initially be appointed for a term of two (2) years. The remaining two (2)
members of the authority shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years. Thereafter, each member shall
serve for a term of three (3) years. All members of the authority shall serve without compensation. (2001
Code § 93.03; amd. Ord. 1548, 1-23-2012; 2012 Code)
D. Vacancies: If a vacancy shall occur in the membership of the authority, by whatever means or cause, the
city commissioners shall appoint a qualified voter of the county to fill the unexpired term of that vacant
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 184/395
position. Members of the authority shall be removed only for causes provided and recognized by the
constitution and statutes of the state in the manner provided, or which may hereafter be provided, for the
removal of municipal officers by general law. (2001 Code § 93.03; amd. Ord. 1548, 1-23-2012)
93.04: OFFICERS; MEETINGS:
Each year, at a time prescribed for the beginning of the term of a new member, or as soon thereafter as
practicable, the authority shall elect a chairperson and a secretary-treasurer from among its members. It shall
be the duty of the chairperson to preside over all meetings of the authority, and it shall be the duty of the
secretary-treasurer to keep a record of the meetings and to perform such additional duties as may be
prescribed by the authority. The authority shall be subject to the open meeting laws of the state, and all
meetings, deliberations and voting of the authority shall be open to the public. The authority shall adopt rules,
regulations and bylaws for conducting its affairs. Four (4) members shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of business at any meeting. The authority shall hold a minimum of six (6) bimonthly meetings and
shall meet at all such other times as it may determine, or on call of the chairperson of the authority. (2001
Code § 93.04)
93.05: FUNCTIONS OF AUTHORITY:
A. The authority shall act in an advisory capacity to the city commission and city manager in planning,
maintaining, equipping, operating, regulating and protecting the Woodward Airport.
B. It shall be the duty of the authority to study, review, analyze and make reports, findings and
recommendations to the city commission concerning the betterment of aviation within the city, and in the
best interests and welfare of the people. (Ord. 1548, 1-23-2012)
93.06: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. City Generally: The city shall have, unless otherwise specifically provided within this chapter, the care,
management and control of all municipally owned, leased or otherwise acquired airports.
B. Airport Manager: The city manager may appoint or employ an airport manager, who shall serve for such
term and upon such conditions, including salary, to be determined by the city.
C. Rules And Regulations: The city shall have the power to adopt, amend, change, alter or repeal any rules,
regulations or bylaws for the maintenance and operation of any and all municipally owned airports and
shall further have the power to enter into the planning, development, construction, enlargement,
improvement, maintenance, operation, regulation and protection of such buildings, structures, facilities or
airports as may be necessary.
D. Master Plan: The city shall have the power to maintain the airport master plan and, with recommendations
from the authority, maintain and improve airports and air navigation facilities, to include buildings,
equipment, and facilities and supplies for servicing aircraft, and for the comfort and accommodation of air
travelers. For such purposes, the city shall use any available airport property now owned, or controlled by
the city, or that may hereafter be acquired by purchase, gift, devise, lease, eminent domain proceedings or
otherwise.
E. Insurance Coverage Required: The city shall maintain insurance coverage for the operation of the airport
and all structures, buildings and facilities. (Ord. 1548, 1-23-2012)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 185/395
93.07: RULES, REGULATIONS AND ORDERS:
A. The authority shall recommend to the city commission rules, regulations, standards and orders for the
maintenance and conduct of the airport, its facilities, properties, services and grounds, including any
activities occurring or proposed to occur thereon. Any person who violates any such rule, regulation,
standard or order, commits a class B offense.
B. All rules, regulations or orders recommended by the authority shall be kept in substantial conformity with the
laws of the state, and any regulation or rule promulgated or standards established pursuant thereto and, as
nearly as may be, with the federal laws governing aeronautics and the rules, regulations and standards
duly issued thereunder. All air navigation facilities established or operated by the airport shall be
supplementary to and coordinated in design and operation with those established by the federal and state
governments. (Ord. 1548, 1-23-2012)
93.08: FISCAL AFFAIRS:
A. Airport Fund: The revenues obtained from the ownership, control or operation of the airport or air navigation
facility, including proceeds from the sale of any airport or portion thereof of air navigation facility property,
shall be deposited in a special fund to be designated as the airport fund, which revenues shall be
appropriated solely to, and used by, the city for the purposes authorized by this chapter. Use of all
revenues generated by industrial activities shall be subject to the approval of the city commission.
B. Disposal Of Airport Property: The city commission, except as may be limited by the terms and conditions of
any grant, loan or agreement, may sell, lease or otherwise dispose of any airport property, be it real or
personal, or a portion thereof or interest therein, in accordance with the laws of the state and the city. (2001
Code § 93.08; amd. Ord. 1548, 1-23-2012)
93.09: PRIVILEGES, OPERATION AND USE:
A. Contracts For Services: The city commission, except as may be limited by the terms and conditions of any
grant, loan or agreement with the federal or state governments, shall have the power in operating an airport
or air navigation facility or service to enter into contract, lease or make other arrangement for any of the
following, with any individual, firm, partnership, corporation, association, body politic, or agency for a term
not to exceed five (5) years:
1. Granting the privilege of using or improving such airport or air navigation facility or any portion or facility
thereof, or space therein for commercial purposes;
2. Conferring the privilege of supplying goods, commodities, things, services or facilities at such airport or
air navigation facilities; or
3. Making available services to be furnished by the city or its agents at such airport or air navigation facility.
B. Terms And Conditions: Provided, the term may exceed five (5) years, yet not to exceed twenty five (25)
years, with prior approval of the city commission. In each case, the city may establish the terms and
conditions and shall authorize the airport manager to fix the charges, rentals or fees for the privileges or
services within the limits established by the city, which shall be reasonable and uniform for the same class
of privilege or service and shall be established with due regard to the property and improvements used and
the expenses of operation to the city. (2001 Code § 93.09; amd. Ord. 1548, 1-23-2012)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 186/395
93.10: CONTRACT FOR AIRPORT OPERATION:
Except as may be limited by the terms and conditions of any grant, loan or agreement with the federal or state
governments, the city may by contract, lease or other arrangement, upon a consideration fixed by it, grant to
any qualified individual, firm, partnership, corporation, association, body politic or agency for a term not to
exceed five (5) years, the privilege of operating, as agent of the city or otherwise, any airport owned or
controlled by the city; provided, that no such person shall be granted any authorization to operate an airport
other than as a public airport or to enter into any contracts, leases or other arrangements in connection with
the operation of the airport which the city might not have undertaken. (Ord. 1548, 1-23-2012)
93.11: GOVERNMENTAL FUNCTIONS:
The acquisition of any land or interest pursuant to this chapter and the laws of the state, the planning,
acquisition, establishment, development, construction, improvement, maintenance, equipment, operation,
regulation, protection and policing of airports and air navigation facilities, including the acquisition or
elimination of airport hazards, and the exercise of any other powers herein granted to the city, are hereby
declared to be public and governmental functions, exercised for a public purpose, and matters of public
necessity. (Ord. 1548, 1-23-2012)
93.12: CHARGES FOR AIRPORT SERVICES:
Charges for services provided by the city at the airport, including, but not limited to, aircraft repair and
maintenance, aircraft storage, hangar rental and gasoline sales, shall be due and payable monthly according
to dates to be determined by the city; and each monthly bill shall indicate thereon the due date. A late payment
charge in an amount equal to one and one-half percent (1.5%) of the total amount due on each monthly bill will
be added in the event the bill is not paid on or before the due date stated on the bill. The due date shall be
thirty (30) days after the bill is mailed. (Ord. 1548, 1-23-2012)
93.13: AIRCRAFT REGULATIONS:
A. Flying Height: All aircraft shall fly at least eight hundred feet (800') above the ground while over the airport
except during landing and takeoff operations.
B. Left Hand Pattern Required: All aircraft shall use a left hand pattern when entering or leaving traffic.
C. Takeoffs, Landings: All takeoffs and landings of aircraft shall be on the designated runways only. All takeoffs
shall be commenced at the end of the active runway and not at its intersection with a taxi runway.
D. Taxi Maneuvers: All taxi maneuvers shall be upon the taxi runways and not on the main runways.
E. Downwind, Crosswinds: No aircraft shall take off or land downwind; and the permission of the municipal
airport manager shall be necessary before practicing crosswind takeoffs or landings.
F. Take Off: All aircraft shall depart from takeoff traffic with a ninety degree (90o) left turn at four hundred feet
(400') above the ground after clearing the end of the active runway, thence at a forty five degree (45o) right
turn for climb out from the pattern.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 187/395
G. Operation Distance To Open Hangar: No aircraft shall have its engine started or running within seventy five
feet (75') of the hangar doors, and no aircraft engine shall be operated in such manner as to propel the
wind into an open hangar.
H. Practice Areas: No aircraft shall use the area of the municipal airport for a practice area; and the municipal
airport manager shall post a map of the designated practice area in the municipal airport office.
I. Prohibited Operation: No person shall operate an aircraft at the municipal airport when the operation is
prohibited by the rules of the federal aviation administration because of weather visibility. (2001 Code
§ 93.13)
93.14: PRIVATE VEHICLES ON RUNWAYS:
No private automobiles or motor vehicles shall be driven upon the ramp or runways, except those authorized
by the municipal airport manager. (2001 Code § 93.14)
93.99: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter or fails to comply therewith or with any of the
requirements thereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not
more than seventy dollars ($70.00), including costs. Each day upon which a violation continues shall be
deemed a separate offense. (2001 Code § 93.99)
Chapter 94
NUISANCES1
94.01: NUISANCE DEFINED:
A. Generally: A "nuisance" consists in unlawfully doing an act, or omitting to perform a duty, which act or
omission either:
1. Annoys, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of others;
2. Offends decency;
3. Unlawfully interferes with, obstructs or tends to obstruct, or renders dangerous for passage, any lake or
navigable river, stream, canal or basin, or any public park, square, street or highway; or
4. In any way renders other persons insecure in life, or in the use of property.
B. Public Nuisance: A "public nuisance" is one which affects at the same time an entire community or
neighborhood, or any considerable number of persons, although the extent of the annoyance or damage
inflicted upon the individuals may be unequal. (2001 Code § 94.01)
94.02: CERTAIN PUBLIC NUISANCES LISTED:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 188/395
A public nuisance includes, but is not limited to, the following acts or omissions:
A. Contaminated Food Or Drink: The sale, or offering for sale, of contaminated food or drink; or the keeping of
a place where such sales or offerings are made.
B. Contagious Disease: The public exposure of a person having a contagious disease.
C. Electrical Interference: The operation or use of any electrical apparatus or machine which materially and
unduly interferes with radio or television reception by others.
D. Obstructions: Any use of a street or sidewalk or a place adjacent thereto which causes crowds of people to
gather so as to obstruct traffic on the street or sidewalk, or which otherwise obstructs traffic thereon, except
as may be authorized by law or ordinance.
E. Flowing Or Falling Liquid: Permitting water or other liquid to flow or fall, or ice or snow to fall, from any
building or structure upon any street or sidewalk.
F. Water Harboring Mosquitoes: All wells, pools, cisterns, or bodies or containers of water in which mosquitoes
breed or are likely to breed, or which are so constructed, formed, conditioned or situated as to endanger
the public safety.
G. Breeding Places For Flies, Disease Germs: Rank weeds or grass, carcasses, accumulations of manure,
refuse, or other things, which are, or are likely to be, breeding places for flies, mosquitoes, vermin or
disease germs.
H. Dangerous Buildings: Any building or structure which is dangerous to the public health or safety because of
damage, decay or other condition.
I. Pits, Holes: Any pit, hole or other thing which is so constructed, formed, conditioned or situated as to
endanger the public safety.
J. Fire, Explosion: Any fire or explosion hazard which endangers the public safety.
K. Sources Of Filth: Any source of filth, cause of sickness, condition conducive to the transmission of disease,
or any other condition adversely affecting the public health.
L. Animals: Animals which threaten or endanger the comfort, repose, health or safety of persons or other
animals, including, but not limited to, stray or wild animals which attack, fight or harass household pets;
animals at large; the persistent and uncontrolled barking, howling or other noise made by an animal, or an
animal which has been impounded more than six (6) times in the previous six (6) months. (2001 Code
§ 94.02)
94.03: PUBLIC NUISANCE UNLAWFUL:
No person shall maintain or create a public nuisance within the city, or permit a public nuisance to remain on
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 189/395
premises under his control or owned by him. (2001 Code § 94.03)
94.04: SUCCESSIVE OWNERS LIABLE:
Every successive owner of property who neglects to abate a continuing public nuisance created by a former
owner, upon or in the use of the property, is liable therefor in the same manner as the one who first created it.
(2001 Code § 94.04)
94.05: ABATEMENT DOES NOT PRECLUDE DAMAGES:
The abatement of a nuisance does not prejudice the right of any person or the city to recover damages for its
past existence. (2001 Code § 94.05)
94.06: EFFECT OF TIME LAPSE:
No lapse of time can legalize a public nuisance amounting to an actual obstruction of public right. (2001 Code
§ 94.06)
94.07: ABATEMENT PROCEDURES:
A. Power: The city commission shall have the power to summarily abate any public nuisance within the city for
the protection of the public health, the public parks and the public water supply, and shall have the power to
summarily abate a public nuisance outside the city.
B. Application For Hearing: Any person or resident of the city may file with the city clerk an application for a
hearing to determine and abate a public nuisance.
C. Notice Of Hearing: The city clerk shall issue a notice of hearing by certified mail with return receipt
requested, to the owner of the property involved and to any other persons alleged or deemed responsible
for or to be causing the public nuisance, with such notice sent to the last known address of such persons
as listed with the office of the Woodward County clerk. If the names or addresses are not known, and the
public peace, health, safety, morals or welfare would not be unduly jeopardized by the necessary delay, a
notice of hearing shall be published once in a paper of general circulation within the city.
D. Public Hearing: The city commission shall then hold a public hearing to determine whether or not the
alleged public nuisance is a public nuisance in fact. The city commission shall have the power to subpoena
and examine witnesses, records and other effects.
E. Order To Abate: If the city commission finds that a public nuisance does in fact exist, it shall direct the
property owner and/or other persons responsible for or causing the public nuisance to abate it within a
specified time.
F. Failure To Comply; Demand For Payment: If the property owner or other persons responsible for or causing
the public nuisance do not abate the public nuisance within the specified time, the city manager shall abate
the public nuisance, or have it abated. The city clerk shall forward a statement of the actual cost and a
demand for payment by certified mail with return receipt requested, to the property owner and/or other
persons responsible for or causing the public nuisance. Until paid, the cost and interest thereon shall
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 190/395
constitute a debt to the city, collectible as other debts may be collected or as provided for in subsection G
of this section.
G. Nonpayment; Lien: If payment under subsection F of this section is not made within six (6) months from the
date of the mailing of the statement, the city clerk shall forward a certified statement of the amount of the
cost to the Woodward County treasurer and the same shall be levied on the property and collected by the
Woodward County treasurer as other taxes authorized by law. The cost and interest thereon shall be a lien
against the property from the date the cost is certified to the Woodward County treasurer, coequal with the
lien of ad valorem taxes and all other taxes and special assessments and prior and superior to all other
titles and liens against the property, and the lien shall continue until the cost and interest thereon shall be
fully paid. (2001 Code § 94.07)
94.08: ABATEMENT BY SUIT IN DISTRICT COURT:
In cases where it is deemed impractical summarily to abate any such nuisance, the city may bring suit in the
