district court for and within Woodward County, and it is hereby made the duty of the city commission, by the
adoption of a resolution to direct the bringing of suit in the proper court for the purpose of abating any such
nuisance. The district court for and within Woodward County shall have jurisdiction of any such case and
power to adjudge and determine any action brought under the provisions hereof, and where it is adjudged that
any such nuisance exists or is maintained and should be abated, the court shall have the power and authority
either by and through a commissioner appointed by the court, or otherwise, to cause the nuisance to be
abated and to assess all the costs thereof, including the costs of suit, against the property on which the
nuisance existed or is maintained, and to declare such costs a judgment against the property and order and
direct the sale of the property for the purpose of satisfying the judgment and shall cause the same to be sold
and proceeds thereof applied to the payment of the costs of abating any nuisance. (2001 Code § 94.08)
94.99: PENALTY:
A. Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or fails to comply
herewith or with any of the requirements hereof, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be
punished as set by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), plus court costs. Each day upon
which a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense.
B. No penalty imposed by and pursuant to this chapter shall interfere with the right of the city or the public also
to apply to the proper courts of the state or city for a mandamus, an injunction, or other appropriate action
against a person who violates or is about to violate any provision of this chapter. (2001 Code § 94.99)
Chapter 95
PARKS
95.01: PARKS OWNED BY CITY:
A. Authority: The city shall provide, maintain, lease and own parks, playgrounds, recreation centers, athletic
fields or grounds, swimming pools, social and community centers, and other facilities and activities on
premises now or hereafter owned or acquired.
B. Parks Owned: The following are parks owned by the city and shall be regulated by the provisions of this
chapter:

C. Future Parks: The provisions of this chapter shall also regulate all parks of the city which may at any time
be acquired or used as parks. (2001 Code § 95.01)
95.02: PARKS AND BEAUTIFICATION BOARD:
A. Created; Membership; Appointment; Composition: There is hereby created a parks and beautification
board, herein referred to as "board". The board shall consist of eight (8) members to be appointed by the
mayor and approved by the city commission. There shall be a minimum of one board member from each of
the wards of the city as established by article II, section II of the city charter. All appointments shall be for
three (3) year terms each beginning on the first Monday of July. Vacancies on the board shall be filled by
the mayor and city commission only for the unexpired term of the member whose vacancy is being filled.
The city park superintendent and cemetery sexton shall be ex officio members.
B. Meetings; Officers: At its first meeting after the first Monday of July of each year, the board shall elect from
among its members a chairperson, a vice chairperson and a secretary. Ex officio members shall not be
allowed to serve as officers of the board. The number of meetings per year of the board created by the
enactment of subsection A of this section is hereby changed from monthly to quarterly, effective January
22, 2002.
C. Removal: Any member of the board may be removed for good cause by the city commission. Good cause
shall include, but not be limited to, neglect of duties, failure to regularly attend board meetings, and missing
more than three (3) consecutive board meetings.
D. Compensation; Reimbursement; Budget: No compensation for the services of board members shall be
allowed. Expenses to be incurred by the board, including, but not limited to, travel, clerical and professional
services, shall be subject to approval by the city commission. Beginning in April 1992, the board shall
submit its proposed budget for the ensuing fiscal year to the city manager.
E. Authority Of Board: The board shall act in an advisory capacity to the mayor and city commission in the
following areas of concern:
1. Parks: Planning, establishing, enlarging, developing, improving, equipping, landscaping and operating all
public parks owned by or under the control of the city;
2. Public Facilities Governed By Separate Boards: Improving the appearance and beauty of airports,
museums, libraries, senior citizen centers, hospitals, emergency medical facilities, industrial parks and all
other public areas and buildings owned by the city, but under the control of special boards or
commissions, but only with the consent and cooperation of the special board or commission having
direct control of such facility;
3. Other Public Areas: Making all other public areas owned by or under the control of the city, including
without limitation, cemeteries, public buildings, street and highway easements and medians, drainage
easements, parking lots, sidewalks and other public ways and lands, as attractive and pleasing to the
eye as possible by appropriate landscaping, signs, exhibits and other improvements; (2001 Code
§ 95.02)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 193/395
4. Woodward Neighborhood Initiative Program: Developing and implementing the Woodward neighborhood
initiative program to provide volunteer assistance to those property owners within the city of Woodward
who have specific code violations and are unable to remedy the violations. The implementation of the
Woodward neighborhood initiative program shall provide the following:
a. Specific requirements for participation in the program, including, but not limited to, financial hardship,
physical/developmental disability, medical hardship, age, active military status;
b. An established selection process;
c. Coordination of volunteers and/or volunteer groups;
d. Method to obtain consents and waivers;
e. Coordination with the city of Woodward, code enforcement division;
f. Establish policies and procedures for accepting or rejecting gifts or donations of property or equipment
to assist in the implementation of the program;
5. Planning And Implementation: Developing and implementing long range plans or the accomplishment of
the objectives stated in subsections E1, E2, E3 and E4 of this section;
6. Grants And Other Assistance: Determining what grants or other assistance, if any, may be available from
time to time from governmental, charitable or other private sources in accomplishing the objectives
stated in subsections E1, E2, E3 and E4 of this section, and pursuing such grants or other assistance;
(Ord. 1574, 1-22-2013)
7. Cooperation With Other Agencies And Organizations: Seeking cooperation and coordination with other
public and private organizations which are or may be involved with beautification of the community,
including, but not limited to, Woodward Pride, Woodward Main Street project, public schools, chamber of
commerce, industrial foundation, United States department of agriculture field station, county
commissioners, county fair board, OSU extension center home demonstration clubs, and civic clubs;
8. Policies And Procedures: Promulgating, establishing and implementing ordinances, rules, regulations,
policies and procedures for protecting, policing, using and maintaining the parks and public areas
mentioned in subsections E1 and E3 of this section; and
9. Gifts And Donations: Establishing policies and procedures for accepting or rejecting gifts of funds and
real or personal property offered to the city under the provisions of section 95.03 of this chapter, or
otherwise, to be used, added to or placed in or upon the parks and other public areas mentioned in
subsections E1 and E3 of this section. (2001 Code § 95.02; amd. Ord. 1574, 1-22-2013)
95.03: GIFTS TO CITY:
Real or personal property may be granted, bequeathed, devised or conveyed to the city for the purpose of the
improvement or ornamentation of such parks or approaches, or for the establishment or maintenance therein
of museums, zoological or other gardens, collections of natural history, observatories, monuments, statues,
fountains or other works of art, upon such trusts and conditions as may be prescribed by the grantors or
devisors thereof, and accepted by the city commission. All property so devised, granted, bequeathed or
conveyed, and the rents, issues, profits and income thereof, shall be subject to the exclusive management,
direction and control of the city. (2001 Code § 95.03)
95.04: PARK REGULATIONS:
No person shall, within a park:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 194/395
A. Discharge firearms.
B. Commit any nuisance or any offense against decency and good morals.
C. Curse, swear or use abusive language, or fight, throw stones or behave in a riotous or disorderly manner.
D. Disturb or interfere with any picnic, social gathering or program of any group of persons.
E. Write upon or mark or deface in any manner, or use in any improper way, any water closet, park seat,
building, fence or other property within the park.
F. Break, cut, mutilate, injure, remove or carry away any trees, shrubs, plants, flowers, stone, stone walk,
bench, chair, seat, structure, fence, property or anything whatsoever in, upon or near any park, or any
street, avenue or highway around the same.
G. Throw stones or rubbish of any kind into any lake, pond, stream or other place in a park, except receptacles
designated for that purpose.
H. Foul, pollute or contaminate in any way any spring, stream, lake or drinking fountain.
I. Use park garbage and/or trash receptacles for the disposal of garbage and/or trash brought from residential
or commercial premises.
J. Paste, affix or inscribe any handbill, poster, card, device or inscription to or upon any fence, structure, or
property of or on any park or any street, avenue or highway around the same.
K. Go or walk upon any space in the parks reserved for flowers or other plants, or otherwise invade any plot
reserved by the city for shrubbery, grass, flowers or any other purpose.
L. Chase, kill, set snares for, or pet any rabbit, squirrel, bird, fish or any animal or thing belonging to the parks
or kept therein, except as provided in the fishing regulations for Crystal Beach Lake as set out in section
95.05 of this chapter.
M. Permit any horse, cow or other domestic animal to go or run at large.
N. Fasten any horse, cow or other animal to any tree, stake, building, post or other fastening.
O. Race horses or automobiles, except with permission therefor by the city commission.
P. Violate any traffic ordinance.
Q. Drive or ride upon the grass or footways or walks or elsewhere than upon the roads provided for the use of
automobiles and other vehicles.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 195/395
R. Drive or ride at a greater speed than fifteen (15) miles per hour.
S. Ride or drive a bicycle, or motorcycle except upon the driveways therefor; and when passing another
vehicle or equestrian from the rear to the front, such persons shall pass to the left side and at a moderate
rate of speed. Bicycles and motorcycles shall not travel more than two (2) abreast.
T. Make a fire for any purpose other than the noncommercial preparation of food on or within fireplaces, pits or
grills provided by the city for such purpose, except with permission therefor by the city manager.
U. Set up any booth, table, stand or other device for vending or retailing any candies, ice cream or other article
whatsoever, except with permission therefor by the city manager.
V. Render any music, vocal or instrumental, or deliver any oration, address, speech, sermon or lecture by and
with the use of amplification equipment, except with permission therefor by the city manager.
W. Use the tennis courts, excepting in accordance to the rules and regulations therefor promulgated by the
parks and beautification board and approved by the city commission.
X. Use the band shell or train, excepting in accordance to the rules and regulations promulgated by the parks
and beautification board and approved by the city commission. (2001 Code § 95.04)
95.05: FISHING REGULATIONS FOR CRYSTAL BEACH LAKE:
A. State Regulations Applicable: Except as modified herein, all state fishing regulations shall be in effect,
including, but not limited to, permit requirements.
B. Methods: Each person shall be limited to one pole or rod. All other fishing methods are prohibited.
C. Introduction Of Fish Prohibited: There shall be no introduction of fish to Crystal Beach Lake by the public or
any source other than those approved by the state department of wildlife conservation. (2001 Code
§ 95.05)
D. Minnows Or Live Bait Restricted: Artificial and live bait, inclusive of worms, minnows and crawfish are
permitted. All bait shall be removed from the premises. (Ord. 1631, 5-16-2016)
E. Swimming: Swimming is prohibited.
F. Flotation Devices Prohibited: Fishing shall be from the banks and fishing piers only. Waders, boats, tubes or
other flotation devices are prohibited. (2001 Code § 95.05)
G. Trout Season; Limit:
1. During the period from October 1 to March 31 of each year, trout fishing shall be permitted pursuant to
fishing regulations found in this section.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 196/395
2. Trout daily limit is six (6). (Ord. 1571, 11-5-2012)
H. Release: All fish caught must be returned to the water immediately or they will count as part of the daily
limits.
I. Adjustments By State: The state department of wildlife conservation may in its discretion adjust the daily
creel and size limits from time to time. (2001 Code § 95.05)
J. Hours Permitted: Fishing will be permitted only during the hours the park is open pursuant to section 95.07
of this chapter. (Ord. 1631, 5-16-2016)
K. Separate Offense: Each violation of the above provisions shall be deemed a separate offense. (2001 Code
§ 95.05)
95.06: FISHING REGULATIONS FOR EXPERIMENT LAKE:
A. State Regulations Applicable: Except as modified herein, all state fishing regulations shall be in effect,
including, but not limited to, license and permit requirements.
B. Rules: The following rules shall be in full force and effect:
1. Methods: Each person shall be limited to one pole or rod. All other fishing methods are prohibited.
2. Introduction Of Fish Prohibited: There shall be no introduction of fish to Experiment Lake by the public or
any source other than those approved by the state department of wildlife conservation. (2001 Code
§ 95.06)
3. Minnows Or Live Bait Restricted: Artificial and live bait, inclusive of worms, minnows and crawfish are
permitted. All bait shall be removed from the premises. (Ord. 1631, 5-16-2016)
4. Swimming: Swimming is prohibited.
5. Flotation Devices: The use of flotation devices is limited to float tubes, canoes, rowboats and other
flotation devices powered by electric motor, oars, paddles or other human powered items. Internal
combustion engines are prohibited.
6. Creel, Size Limits: Daily creel and size limits:
a. Largemouth bass daily limit: Catch and release only;
b. Channel catfish daily limit: Three (3) fish; no minimum length;
c. Other: No limits as to numbers or size.
7. Release: All fish will count as part of the daily limits unless returned to the water and released
immediately.
8. Adjustments: The state department of wildlife conservation and/or the city may in its discretion adjust the
daily creel and size limits from time to time. (2001 Code § 95.06)
9. Hours Permitted; Camping Prohibited: Fishing will be permitted only during the hours the park is open
pursuant to section 95.07 of this chapter. Overnight camping is prohibited. (2001 Code § 95.06; amd.
Ord. 1631, 5-16-2016)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 197/395
C. Separate Offense: Each violation of the above provisions shall be deemed a separate offense. (2001 Code
§ 95.06)
95.07: POLICE JURISDICTION; PARK HOURS:
For the purpose of enforcing this chapter, all parks within or without the city now or hereafter owned by, or
under the control of the city, are hereby placed under the police jurisdiction of the city. The parks shall be open
to the general public from six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. daily, from November 1 to
March 31 and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. to twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight from April 1 to October 31, except as
provided herein. The chief of police may determine earlier or later opening and closing times of the parks to
accommodate special events and activities taking place scheduled therein. Any member of the police
department may arrest, without warrant, in any such park, any person who has broken any park regulation or
other ordinance in the presence of the officer and the municipal court shall have jurisdiction of all such
violations. (2001 Code § 95.07)
95.08: ENFORCEMENT:
The state department of wildlife conservation and the city shall have joint and several control over the
enforcement of the fishing regulations of Crystal Beach Lake as set forth in section 95.05 of this chapter. The
municipal court shall have jurisdiction over all such violations. (2001 Code § 95.08)
95.99: PENALTY:
A. Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or fails to comply
therewith or with any of the requirements thereof, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall
be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), plus court costs. Each day upon
which a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. (2001 Code § 95.99)
B. The maximum penalty for any single violation of section 95.05 of this chapter shall be a fine of one hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00), plus court costs. (2001 Code § 95.99; amd. 2012 Code)
C. No penalty imposed by and pursuant to this chapter shall interfere with the right of the city or the public also
to apply to the proper courts of the state or city for a mandamus, an injunction, or other appropriate action
against a person who violates or is about to violate any provision of this chapter. (2001 Code § 95.99)
Chapter 96
CEMETERIES
96.01: WOODWARD MUNICIPAL CEMETERY:
The City shall own and operate the Woodward Municipal Cemetery, known as Elmwood Cemetery, and other
cemeteries as hereafter acquired. (2001 Code § 96.01)
96.02: CEMETERY CARE FUND CREATED:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 198/395
Twenty five percent (25%) of all monies received from the sale of lots and interments shall be segregated and
set aside as a permanent fund to be known as a Cemetery Care Fund. The Cemetery Care Fund shall be
expended in purchasing land for cemeteries and for making capital improvements as defined in 11 Oklahoma
Statutes section 17-110, and as amended. The balance of the fund shall be invested by the City Commission.
The interest from any investments shall be used for the same purposes as the principal or in improving, caring
for, and embellishing the lots, walks, drives, parks and other necessary improvements in the cemeteries. (2001
Code § 96.02)
96.03: PERPETUAL CARE FUND:
Donations, deposits or bequests may be made in trust for the special care of specified lots, monuments or
mausoleums in the cemetery. These funds shall be segregated and set aside as a permanent fund to be
known as the "Perpetual Care Fund". A separate account shall be kept of each amount so deposited, donated
and bequeathed for special care of specified lots. The Perpetual Care Fund may be invested in like manner as
the Cemetery Care Fund, and only the interest derived from the fund shall be used in the care, maintenance
and repair of such lots, monuments and mausoleums, unless otherwise specified by the donor. (2001 Code
§ 96.03)
96.04: CEMETERY EXPENSES AND COLLECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the City Clerk to receipt for all monies received from the sale of lots or from interments,
or from any other source and to deposit such funds with the City Treasurer, who shall deposit the same in the
City Treasury and the Cemetery Care Fund as above provided. Expenses incurred by reason of the upkeep,
repair and adornment of the cemetery may be paid by the City Treasurer on claims filed with and approved by
the City Commission. (2001 Code § 96.04)
96.05: CITY CLERK TO HAVE BOND AND MAKE REPORT:
A. Bond Required: It shall be the duty of the City Clerk, before entering upon his duties, to make a bond in the
sum twice the amount of the funds likely to come under his control at any time during his term of office,
such bond to be approved by the City Commission, and the amount of such bond may be increased by the
City Commission at any time.
B. Report: The City Clerk shall, on the first Monday in January and July of each year, and at such other times
as may be requested, make a full report to the City Commission, of all lots sold, interments made, and all
monies received by him. (2001 Code § 96.05)
96.06: REQUEST FOR TAX LEVY FOR SUPPORT OF CEMETERY:
(Rep. by Ord. 1678, 1-22-2019)
96.07: CONVEYANCE OF CEMETERY LOTS; ABANDONED LOTS:
A. Conveyance; Certificate: Lots in the cemetery shall be conveyed by certificate signed by the Mayor and
countersigned by the City Clerk, under the Seal of the City. The certificate shall show the price for which
the lots are sold and specify that the person to whom it is issued is the owner of the lot or lots described
therein by number, as laid down in the plat, for the purpose of interment. The certificate shall vest in the
purchaser and his heirs a right to the lot or lots, for the sole purpose of interment, under the regulations of
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 199/395
the City Commission. The certificate shall be entitled to record in the Office of the County Clerk without
further acknowledgment, and the description of lots by number shall be sufficient for the purpose of record.
B. Abandoned Lots: Cemetery lots, or spaces within lots previously conveyed pursuant to this chapter, may be
deemed by the Mayor or the City Manager to have been abandoned by the record holder thereof upon the
happening of any one of the following:
1. Receipt by the City Clerk of a written acknowledgment that the lot or space will not be used, executed by
the original grantee, the spouse of the original grantee, or duly empowered trustee, attorney in fact or
personal representative of the original grantee.
2. Failure to use the lot or space for burial within ninety (90) years following the date of a conveyance of
same filed with the City Clerk or the County Clerk.
3. Failure to use the lot or space for burial within fifty (50) years of the date of conveyance filed with the
City Clerk or County Clerk, and upon the filing of an affidavit by any funeral director or employee of the
City that the lot or space is vacant, and upon the absence of response from the record owner or spouse
or a duly empowered trustee, attorney in fact or personal representative within ninety (90) days after
written request from the City Clerk by certified mail to the record owner at his or her last known address,
and publication of the request in a daily newspaper of general circulation published in the City that the
record owner, spouse or duly empowered trustee, attorney in fact or personal representative of the
record owner show cause why said lot or space should not be deemed abandoned. (2001 Code § 96.07)
96.08: CONVEYANCE OR DEVISE OF LOT IN TRUST:
Any burial lot in the cemetery may be conveyed or devised by the owner to and held by the City in perpetual
trust for the purpose of its preservation as a place of burial. The lot so conveyed shall thereafter remain
inalienable by act of the parties, but the right to use the same as a place of burial of the dead of the family of
the owner and his descendants from generation to generation shall remain, unless the deed of conveyance in
trust shall provide that interments in such lot shall be confined to the bodies of specified persons, in which
case the lot shall be forever preserved as the burial place of the persons specified in the deed and shall never
be used for any other purpose whatever. However, no conveyance in trust shall be made without the consent
of the City Commission. (2001 Code § 96.08)
96.09: LIEN ON CEMETERY LOTS FOR UPKEEP CHARGES; ENFORCEMENT:
A. Lien: The City shall have a lien on any unused lot when a written contract provides for upkeep payments on
such lot and the upkeep payments have been unpaid for a continuous period of five (5) years. Where more
than one lot has been purchased in a group of lots, the provisions of this section shall not apply.
B. Enforcement Of Lien: After filing the lien with the County District Court Clerk, the lien may be enforced by
civil action. (2001 Code § 96.09)
96.10: REMOVAL OF REMAINS TO OTHER GRAVESITES; UNMARKED GRAVES:
When the bodily remains of an unknown person are discovered in an unidentified and unmarked grave of the
cemetery, the remains may be removed to some other gravesite within the cemetery, at the expense of the
City, if no record exists as to a sale or conveyance of the lot and the City is without knowledge that a body has
been buried in the gravesite, in the event that the lot is sold to another person. An application for approval of
the disinterment and removal of the bodily remains shall be first filed with, and approval obtained from, the
State Health Department. (2001 Code § 96.10)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 200/395
96.11: PERMIT REQUIRED; FEES:
A. Application; Fee: All persons shall, before beginning work of erecting, cleaning or repairing of memorials,
make written application to the City Clerk, on forms furnished by him, providing all of the information
requested, including satisfactory evidence of the applicant's ability to properly perform the work proposed,
and shall pay the City Clerk the applicable permit fee as follows:
Single markers $ 5.00
Double markers 10.00
Monuments 10.00
Aboveground vaults or mausoleums 50.00
Government grave marker 0.00
(Ord. 1678, 1-22-2019)
B. Fees Deposited: All permit fees shall be deposited by the City Clerk in the General Fund of the City. (2001
Code § 96.11)
C. Cemetery Lot Fee: A fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be charged per cemetery lot.
D. Fees For Services:
Monday - Friday Holidays, Saturday And Sunday
Interment $200.00 $300.00
Disinterment 200.00 250.00
Infant interment 100.00 150.00
Cremation 100.00 150.00
Concrete cut 100.00 150.00
Setting funeral home equipment 100.00 150.00
(Ord. 1678, 1-22-2019)
96.12: CEMETERY REGULATIONS:
A. Trespassing: No person shall trespass upon the grounds of the cemetery, or desecrate any grave or marker,
or violate any of the rules and regulations made by the City Commission.
B. Memorials, Mausoleums Or Vaults: Permanent and temporary memorials of cement, artificial stone,
composition, wood, tin or iron shall not be permitted. All markers, monuments, mausoleums or vaults,
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 201/395
which part or any part that shows above the surface, must be made of natural marble, granite or bronze,
and shall be of first grade material and carry a certificate of guarantee as to quality and workmanship. All
concrete or part concrete burial vaults or so called individual mausoleums, all steel, copper or bronze
vaults, not being made of natural marble or granite shall be buried underground with at least eighteen
inches (18") of earth covering them, except on lots now having said work.
C. Curbs Or Coping: There shall be no curbs or coping unless the owner of the lot is granted special
permission by the City Manager. If curbs or coping are allowed, they must be a natural stone, marble,
granite or concrete.
D. Placement Of Monuments And Markers: All monuments and markers shall be placed in the center of a
concrete foundation, which shall be not more than six inches (6") nor less than five inches (5") each way
than size of the base of the marker, and such foundation shall be placed so that the top is level with the
surrounding ground. Foundation for grave markers or monuments shall be no less than six inches (6").
Concrete shall consist of one part portland cement and five (5) parts clean sand. All dirt must be removed
from lot unless otherwise directed by the sexton.
E. Marker Posts: Lot corner marker posts, whenever used, shall be of monumental stone placed level with
grade. Initials shall be incised (cut in), not raised. Posts shall be finished where they abut on adjacent lots.
All corner posts will be set by the cemetery and a reasonable charge made for this work.
F. Duplication Of Monument Design: Duplication of the design of any monument or mausoleum shall not be
permitted in a locality in noticeable proximity to the original without the permission of the owner of the
original.
G. Work To Cease During Funeral: All work of any description shall cease while a funeral or interment is being
conducted nearby. It shall be required that trucks and workers withdraw to a reasonable distance from the
location of the funeral service.
H. Solicitation: Approaching the bereaved within the cemetery for the purpose of soliciting any business shall
not be permitted.
I. Advertising: Advertising of any description shall be prohibited within the cemetery.
J. Unsightly Monuments: Should any monument, mausoleum or tomb become unsightly, dilapidated or a
menace to visitors, the City Commission shall have the right, at the expense of the lot owner, either to
correct the condition or to remove the same.
K. Permanent Decorations: Permanent decorations which interfere with the maintenance and mowing of the
grounds, such as birdbaths, statuary, vases or other items not directly affixed to the foundation of
headstones, burial markers or curbing shall not be allowed. (2001 Code § 96.12)
L. Maintenance: When watering, only the use of soaker hoses is permitted. The use of regular sprinklers is not
permitted. (Ord. 1602, 7-7-2014)
96.99: PENALTY:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 202/395
A. Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or fails to comply
therewith or with any of the requirements thereof, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall
be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day upon which a violation
continues shall be deemed a separate offense.
B. No penalty imposed by and pursuant to this chapter shall interfere with the right of the City or the public also
to apply to the proper courts of the State or City for a mandamus, an injunction, or other appropriate action
against a person who violates or is about to violate any provision of this chapter. (2001 Code § 96.99)
Chapter 97
STREETS AND SIDEWALKS
General Provisions
97.01: STREET NAMING PROCEDURES:
A. All major thoroughfares of the city running east and west shall be termed "avenues" and bear a name. All
major thoroughfares running north and south shall be termed "streets" and bear a number, and the
numbers shall begin at the present First Street and increase progressively with each street therefrom to the
west.
B. For the names of avenues and streets of the city as formerly designated, reference is hereby made to the
official plats of the city and the additions thereto as now on file.
C. The city commission shall name each additional avenue and number each additional street when the same
is officially platted, dedicated and accepted. (2001 Code § 97.01)
97.02: HOUSE AND BUILDING NUMBERING:
A. Buildings And Houses To Be Numbered:
1. All residence and business houses and buildings fronting upon public avenues running north and south,
shall be numbered from Canadian Avenue, commencing with numbers 101 and 102, with numbering
increasing north and south from Canadian Avenue in the ratio of one hundred (100) numbers to each
and every block. There shall be even numbers on the east side of each street, and odd numbers on the
west side of each street. All numbering north of Canadian Avenue shall be prefixed with the word "north".
2. All residence and business houses and buildings fronting upon public streets running east and west shall
be numbered from First Street, commencing with the numbers 101 and 102, with the numbering
increasing east and west from First Street in the ratio of one hundred (100) numbers to each and every
block. There shall be even numbers on the north side of each street, and odd numbers on the south side
of each street. All numbering east of First Street shall be prefixed with the word "east".
3. The owner or occupant of each residence, or business house or building, shall place upon the house or
building, the appropriate number, in script or numerals, in figures not less than three inches (3") in height,
in a conspicuous place so that the number may be easily seen from the public avenue or street.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 203/395
B. Mobile Homes Within Trailer Park To Be Numbered: The owner of a mobile home park or trailer park shall
permanently number each lot therein with consecutive numbers beginning with the number 1, with such
number to be posted on a sign, stake or by other means at the front of each lot so that it may be easily
seen from the public avenue or street, or the park's principal service road.
C. Apartments To Be Numbered: Owners of apartment complexes shall number each apartment therein with
consecutive numbers beginning with the number 1, with the appropriate number, in script or numerals, in
figures not less than three inches (3") in height, to be posted in a conspicuous place so that the number
may be easily seen. (2001 Code § 97.02)
Obstruction And Use Of Public Ways
97.15: OBSTRUCTION OF PUBLIC WAYS PROHIBITED:
A. No person, firm or corporation shall obstruct or cause to be obstructed any avenue, street, alley, sidewalk or
other public way, in any manner as to interfere to any extent in the use thereof of the public, or as to
interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic or parking thereon, excepting as may be necessary for the
loading and unloading of any merchandise or farm products.
B. No person, firm or corporation shall place upon or permit to be placed upon any avenue, street, alley,
sidewalk or other public way any goods, wares, articles of merchandise, or any other obstruction, without
consent from the city manager. (2001 Code § 97.15)
97.16: OBSTRUCTION WHEN CONSTRUCTION WORK IN PROGRESS:
A person, firm or corporation may occupy a portion of a sidewalk as may be necessary for the placing of
building materials during the erection of buildings or the improvements thereof, but to no greater extent than
shall be necessary for such purpose; and such use shall be permitted only with written consent of the director
of code enforcement, which shall prescribe the boundaries of such obstruction and the manner in which traffic
along the sidewalk shall be provided. (2001 Code § 97.16; amd. 2012 Code)
97.17: LIMITATION ON DRAINAGE OF STORMWATER:
No owner of any house or building shall drain or allow to be drained stormwater from the roof of the house or
building upon the sidewalks, or upon the space between the property line and the curb line of any avenue or
street. (2001 Code § 97.17)
97.18: LITTERING OF PUBLIC WAYS PROHIBITED:
No owner or operator of a filling station or other place of business, or any agent or employee thereof, shall
allow or cause to be allowed any water, grease or other fluid to flow or drain into, upon, over or across any
avenue, street, parking lot and space, sidewalk or other public way. (2001 Code § 97.18; amd. 2012 Code)
97.19: SIDEWALKS NOT TO BECOME HAZARDS:
No owner of property abutting upon a sidewalk shall permit the sidewalk adjacent to the property to become a
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 204/395
hazard to persons using the sidewalk. (2001 Code § 97.19)
97.20: REPAIRS BY CITY BILLED TO PROPERTY OWNER:
The city manager may give written notice to the owner of property abutting upon a sidewalk that the sidewalk
adjacent to the property has become a hazard, and detail the repair and work that needs to be done to
eliminate the hazard, and set a reasonable time period for such repair and work. If the property owner does
not perform such repair or work within the stated time period, the city manager may cause the sidewalk to be
repaired and cleared, and shall forward to the property owner a statement of actual cost, which the property
owner shall pay within thirty (30) days of receipt of such statement. (2001 Code § 97.20)
97.21: PLAY NOT PERMITTED UPON PUBLIC WAYS:
Except as provided in section 70.056 of this code, no person shall play in or on the avenues, streets, alleys,
sidewalks or other public ways. (2001 Code § 97.21; amd. 2012 Code)
97.22: TREES AND SHRUBBERY TO BE TRIMMED:
A. The owner or tenant of property abutting any avenue, street, alley, sidewalk or other public way shall cut
and trim all trees, grass, weeds and shrubbery growing in the parking lots and spaces between the
sidewalks and the roadway, or within cracks or breaks in the sidewalks adjacent to the property.
B. The owner or tenant of property abutting any avenue, street, alley, sidewalk or other public way shall cut
and trim all trees, grass, weeds and shrubbery in such manner that the boughs or limbs thereof shall not
obstruct free and convenient passage and travel along the public ways. Such trees and shrubbery shall be
trimmed so that the lowest branches or foliage shall not be lower than fourteen feet (14') above the avenue,
street or alley, nor lower than eight feet (8') above the sidewalk. (2001 Code § 97.22)
97.23: OBSTRUCTION OF VISION NOT PERMITTED AT INTERSECTION:
The owner or tenant of property abutting any avenue, street, alley or other public way, shall not permit trees,
grass, weeds and shrubbery, or fences or other improvements, to constitute an obstruction to the clear sight
and vision of operators of motor vehicles approaching intersections. (2001 Code § 97.23)
97.24: RAILROADS TO IMPROVE AVENUES, STREETS AND ALLEYS:
A. When a railway occupies any portion of an avenue or street with its tracks running in a general direction of
such avenue or street, either on or adjacent thereto, the railway company shall improve the space between
its tracks and two feet (2') on either side thereof in the same manner that the remainder of the street is to
be, or has been, improved, or with such other satisfactory material as the city commission by motion or
resolution may approve.
B. When a railway crosses any avenue or street that is being or has been paved, the railway company shall
pave as much of the avenue or street as is occupied by its tracks and two feet (2') on each side, using the
same material as is to be, or has been, used on the avenue or street, or such other satisfactory material as
the city commission by motion or resolution may approve.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 205/395
C. When a railway occupies an alley with its tracks, the railway company shall improve, gutter, drain and grade
such alley, and shall surface or pave it using the same material which is to be, or has been, used on the
alley, or with such other satisfactory material as the city commission by motion or resolution may approve.
D. When more than one pair of tracks cross a street within a distance of one hundred feet (100'), measuring
from inside rail to inside rail, the railway company shall grade, gutter, drain and curb the avenue or street
area between its respective pairs of tracks, and surface or pave it with the same material which is to be, or
has been used, on the avenue or street, or such other satisfactory material as the city commission by
motion or resolution may approve. Railway companies shall keep all such improvements made by them in
a good state of repair at all times. (2001 Code § 97.24)
97.25: SIDEWALKS TO BE CONSTRUCTED BY RAILWAY COMPANIES:
Railway companies shall construct sidewalks crossing their rights of way, using the same material as is used
in the adjacent sidewalks, or such other satisfactory material as the city commission by motion or resolution
may approve. The railway companies shall construct sidewalks on both sides of the avenues and streets when
both sides are used by pedestrians. The railway companies shall keep such sidewalks in a good state of repair
at all times. (2001 Code § 97.25)
Administration
97.35: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person, firm or corporation shall use avenues, streets, alleys and public ways within the corporate limits of
the city without first obtaining a permit from the city clerk; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to
the public utilities operating within the city under valid franchise, nor to public utilities operating within the city
who pay a gross production tax in lieu of a franchise. (2001 Code § 97.35)
97.36: APPLICATION TO BE FILED:
Before a permit shall be issued granting permission for the applicant to use the city avenues, streets, alleys
and public ways, a written application must first be filed with the city clerk, which application must contain the
following information:
A. Name of applicant.
B. Use for which the permit is intended.
C. Duration of the proposed use.
D. The service to be rendered by the applicant.
E. A statement that the applicant will conform to all restrictions imposed by the city in applicant's use of the
permit.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 206/395
F. A statement that the applicant will assume all liability for personal injuries and property damage caused by
applicant's property in applicant's use of the avenues, streets, alleys and public ways.
G. A statement that the applicant's use of the avenues, streets, alleys and public ways shall not be an
exclusive use thereof, and that the applicant's use shall be subject to the use of the same by residents of
the city and franchise users and other users. (2001 Code § 97.36)
97.37: HEARING ON APPLICATION; CONTENTS OF PERMIT:
The application above required shall be set for hearing before the city commission at the first regular meeting
after the filing of the application. At the hearing before the city commission, the city commission shall
determine whether or not a need for a service rendered by the applicant exists and determine whether or not
the use of the avenues, streets and public ways by the applicant will jeopardize the rights of the city or others
holding franchises or paying gross production tax in lieu of a franchise. If, in the judgment of the city
commission, a permit should be granted, the city commission shall instruct the city clerk to issue a permit to
the applicant. All permits issued under this section shall specifically provide the following:
A. The applicant must assume full liability of any and all personal injury or property damage caused by the
applicant's use of the avenues, streets, alleys and public ways within the city.
B. The use by the applicant of the avenues, streets, alleys and public ways shall be subject to the normal use
of the same by residents of the city for travel and subject to the use by other public utilities, and that such
permit shall not be considered as exclusive.
C. The applicant shall install, service and maintain its properties in good condition at all times, and that, in the
event wires, cables and poles are used, they shall be so placed as not to interfere with the normal use of
the avenues and alleys by the public for travel.
D. The applicant shall file with the city a map showing the location of its properties within the avenues, streets,
alleys and public ways of the city.
E. The applicant shall be subject to regulation and supervision of the city and agrees to move its installations
when, in the judgment of the city, such installations should be moved.
F. The permit shall not be assigned except on written approval of the city commission.
G. All such permits shall expire on April 30 in each year, and shall be renewable from year to year. (2001 Code
§ 97.37)
97.38: PERMIT FEE:
Before issuance of a permit, the city clerk shall collect a permit fee determined as follows:
A. A minimum permit fee of five dollars ($5.00), payable in advance, and the equivalent of two percent (2%) of
the gross revenue for the first year, which shall be due and payable at the end of such year.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 207/395
B. After the first year, the city shall be entitled to an annual permit fee equivalent to two percent (2%) of the
gross revenue of the applicant, which shall be due and payable monthly on the tenth day of each month.
C. The holder of the permit shall allow the city clerk to examine its books and records in determining the
amount of permit fee to be assessed and charged.
D. The city commission, for good cause, may waive the permit fee set forth in this subsection. (2001 Code
§ 97.38)
97.39: AUTHORITY AND PROCEDURES TO CLOSE PUBLIC WAYS OR EASEMENTS:
A. Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply, unless the context clearly
indicates or requires a different meaning:
CLOSING: A legislative act of the city commission discontinuing the public use of a public way or easement
without affecting title to real property.
EASEMENT: Right in real property as set forth in 60 Oklahoma Statutes section 49, as amended.
PUBLIC WAY: An avenue, street, boulevard, alley, lane or thoroughfare open for public use.
B. Authority Of City To Close: The city commission shall have the power by ordinance to close to the public
use any public way or easement within the city whenever deemed necessary or expedient.
C. Notice Required: The city commission shall give written notice of any proposed closing of a public way or
easement to any holder of a franchise or others deemed by the city commission to have a special right or
privilege granted by ordinance to use the public way or easement at least thirty (30) days prior to passage
of any ordinance providing for closing of a public way or easement.
D. Right To Reopen: The city commission shall retain the absolute right to reopen the public way or easement
without expense to the city commission and may reopen by:
1. Its own motion; or
2. Upon application of the property owners owning more than one-half (1/2) in area of the property abutting
on the public way or easement previously closed.
E. Facilities Not Affected: Closing of the public way or easement shall not affect the right to maintain, repair,
reconstruct, operate or remove utility, public service corporation or transmission company facilities of
service therein, nor shall such closing affect private ways existing by operation of law unless released in
writing executed by the owners thereof. (2001 Code § 97.39)
97.99: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter, or fails to comply
therewith or with any of the requirements thereof, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be
punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus court costs. Each day upon which a
violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. (2001 Code § 97.99)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 208/395
Chapter 98
ALARMS
98.01: TITLE:
This chapter may be cited as the ALARM ORDINANCE. (Ord. 1624, 11-2-2015)
98.02: PURPOSE AND EXCLUSIONS:
A. The purpose of this chapter is to encourage alarm users to assume increased responsibility for maintaining
the mechanical reliability and the proper use of alarm systems, to prevent unnecessary police and fire
response to false alarms and to protect the emergency response capability of the city. By coming to the
understanding that, other than actual criminal activity or a fire emergency, there is no valid reason for an
alarm to activate, the police and firefighters can better target responses to actual emergencies.
B. This chapter draws a distinction between responses to requests by individual persons and responses to
requests made by mechanical devices. It is the policy of the police and fire departments to respond to valid
requests for service. Nothing in this chapter lessens or increases that responsibility. It is also understood
that many requests for service to mechanical activations are not valid calls for service and the resident
does not want the police or firefighters to respond.
C. The reduction of false alarms will significantly improve the effectiveness of the police and fire department
responders.
D. No provision within this chapter shall be construed as to apply to any building, structure or facility owned,
controlled or occupied by the United States Of America, the state, or any county or city of this state. (Ord.
1624, 11-2-2015)
98.03: DEFINITIONS:
Terms, which are not defined in this chapter, shall have their ordinarily accepted meanings or such as the
context may apply. For the purpose of this chapter, each of the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings given below:
ALARM DISPATCH REQUEST: A notification to the police or fire personnel of the city from an alarm industry
business that an alarm system has been activated.
ALARM INDUSTRY BUSINESS: Any entity having obtained a license pursuant to the provisions of the alarm
industry act of the state who sells, leases, maintains, services, repairs, alters, replaces, moves, installs or
monitors any alarm system.
ALARM RESPONSE: An actual police or fire response to the location of an alarm system resulting from an
alarm dispatch request.
ALARM SITE: A single premises or location served by an alarm system.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 209/395
ALARM SYSTEM: Any mechanism, equipment or device which is designed to detect the presence of a fire, or
an unauthorized entry or activity in any building or on any property, or to direct attention to a fire, robbery,
burglary, or other emergency in progress, and to signal the above occurrences either by a local or audible
alarm or by a silent or remote alarm, directly or indirectly to the police or fire department. The following devices
shall not constitute alarm systems within the meaning of this chapter:
A. Devices which do not activate alarms that are audible, visible, or perceptible outside the protected
premises;
B. Devices which are not installed, operated or used for the purpose of reporting an emergency, either
directly or by third party, to the police or fire department;
C. Alarm devices affixed to motor vehicles; and
D. Alarm devices installed on a temporary basis by the police or fire department.
ALARM USER: The person or persons, over the age of eighteen (18), owning or leasing the real property
where an alarm system is located.
CHIEF OF POLICE: The duly appointed, qualified or acting chief of police of the city of Woodward, or the
authorized representative.
DURESS ALARM: A silent alarm signal generated by the manual activation of a device intended to signal a
crises situation requiring police response.
FALSE ALARM: The activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, the negligence of
the alarm business operator or his employees or agents, or the negligence of the owner, user or lessee of an
alarm or his employees or agents, or which otherwise elicits a response by a law enforcement agency or the
fire department when a situation requiring such response does not in fact exist. A false alarm shall also mean
the activation of an alarm, the purpose of which is to communicate or indicate a specific emergency situation,
when in fact that specific emergency situation does not exist. Such terminology does not include, for example,
alarms activated by utility line mishaps, tornados, earthquakes, or other violent conditions of nature, or other
conditions clearly beyond the control of the alarm manufacturer, installer, owner or user.
FALSE ALARM DISPATCH: An alarm dispatch request when the responding personnel finds no evidence of
criminal activity or fire emergency after having completed an investigation of the location. An alarm dispatch
request that is canceled by the alarm user or the alarm industry business prior to the time an officer or
firefighter reaches the location shall not be considered a false alarm dispatch. Any alarm response that is first
designated as a false alarm dispatch but where the alarm user later shows convincing evidence of criminal
activity or a fire emergency to the investigating personnel and files a police or fire report, shall be subject to the
judgment of the city manager, to be amended to not be recorded as false alarm dispatch.
FIREFIGHTER: Any or all firefighters being career or volunteer employed by the city of Woodward fire
department.
HOLDUP ALARM: A silent alarm signal generated by the manual activation of a device intended to signal a
robbery in progress.
IN-STATION ALARMS: An alarm system which is connected to the police station communications area or the
fire department by telephone or other means which summons emergency assistance.
MONITORING: The process by which an alarm industry business receives signals from an alarm system and
relays an alarm dispatch request to the city for the purpose of summoning police or fire response to the alarm
site.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 210/395
PERSON: Every natural person, firm, partnership, association or corporation.
POLICE: Any or all sworn officers of the city of Woodward police department.
VERIFY: An attempt by an alarm industry business to contact the alarm site by telephonic or other electronic
means, whether or not actual contact with a person is made, prior to an alarm dispatch request, in an attempt
to avoid a false alarm dispatch. Monitoring companies are required to attempt verification on all alarms before
contacting the police or fire department. (Ord. 1624, 11-2-2015)
98.04: ALARM BUSINESSES; REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
A. No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the alarm industry business, as defined in 59 Oklahoma
Statutes sections 1800.1 through 1800.16, unless pursuant to the state alarm industry act.
B. Every alarm business selling, leasing or furnishing any alarm system within the city shall furnish the alarm
user with instructions that provide adequate information to enable the alarm user to operate the alarm
system properly and to obtain service for the alarm system.
C. Every alarm business doing business with alarm users shall be required to register with the city clerk each
calendar year. Registration shall include copies of the state license of the company or individual providing
services to the alarm user and such other information as the city clerk deems appropriate. (Ord. 1624, 11-
2-2015)
98.05: RESERVED:
(Ord. 1624, 11-2-2015)
98.06: FALSE ALARMS; CHARGES:
A. When records of the appropriate emergency service indicate three (3) false alarms from a single alarm user
within one calendar year, city of Woodward personnel who are commissioned by the Woodward police
chief as law enforcement officers, may cite said users as provided by provisions set forth in section 98.99
of this chapter. (Ord. 1624, 11-2-2015)
98.07: CERTAIN INTERCONNECTIONS PROHIBITED:
Except for city owned locations, it is unlawful for any person to program an automatic dialing device to any
telephone line which, when activated, dials the digits 9-1-1. It is unlawful for an alarm user to fail to disconnect
or reprogram an automatic dialing device which is programmed to dial the digits 9-1-1. (Ord. 1624, 11-2-2015)
98.08: SYSTEM PERFORMANCE REVIEW:
A system performance review is evidenced by a thorough inspection of an alarm system that ensures proper
operation and design and is conducted by an alarm industry business representative. A system performance
review shall cover, but not be limited to, inspection of:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 211/395
A. All contacts, trips, motion detectors, pressure pads, breakage sensors or other such instruments to ensure
their proper function and design for the system.
B. The battery backup system to provide a minimum four (4) hour uninterrupted power supply to the system in
the event of a power outage.
C. Wiring and electronic systems to establish their proper function and design for the system.
D. Automated dialing system to ensure immediate release of the phone line after alarm notification. (Ord.
1624, 11-2-2015)
98.99: PENALTY:
A. Violation of this chapter shall constitute an offense and shall be punished, upon conviction, by a fine of not
more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) per occurrence, plus court costs.
B. In addition to the penalties provided for in this section, the chief of police is authorized to take appropriate
legal action to require the disconnection of any alarm system operated in violation of this chapter, including,
but not limited to, disconnection of the alarm system through injunctive relief in the district court. (Ord.
1624, 11-2-2015)
Title 11
BUSINESS REGULATIONS
Chapter 110
GENERAL BUSINESS LICENSING
110.01: LICENSE TAX LEVIED ON CERTAIN PERSONS:
A license tax is hereby levied on every person engaging in, exercising or pursuing any of the following
businesses, professions, trades, occupations or privileges in this city, in the amount respectively indicated:
A. For each domino parlor, pool or billiard hall, family amusement center, bowling alley, skating rink, an annual
license tax of fifty dollars ($50.00).
B. For each show, exhibition, circus, street fair, carnival, menagerie, wrestling match, or entertainment of any
kind which charges admission, including all activities under its auspices, excluding movie theaters
permanently located within the city, and events sponsored by nonprofit organizations that have an active
chapter within the city, a license tax of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per day, or twenty five dollars ($25.00) per
week, or fifty dollars ($50.00) per year.
C. Each landowner, lessee, person, partnership and/or corporation which allows real estate which it owns,
leases, controls or has an interest in to be used for sales of any kind by peddlers, vendors or solicitors shall
obtain a bond for the protection of the public and the purchaser in the minimum amount of five thousand
dollars ($5,000.00), which shall be filed with the city clerk prior to any sales being made. In addition, each
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 212/395
landowner, lessee, person, partnership and/or corporation shall file with the city clerk a certified list of
employees and/or agents who are conducting sales by name, address, telephone number and social
security number, and employees and/or agents, whether employees, agents or mere peddlers, vendors or
solicitors, shall be required to pay the license tax in subsection A of this section, for solicitations allowed by
landowners, lessees, persons, partnerships and/or corporations, and shall provide a sales tax permit to the
city clerk.
D. Any pawnshop, junk store, secondhand store, secondhand automobile parts store, junk or salvage yard,
and self-service stations, an annual license tax of zero dollars ($0.00).
E. For taxi service, an annual license of twenty five dollars ($25.00). (2001 Code § 110.01)
110.02: PUBLIC VENDOR, PEDDLER LICENSE AND BOND:
A. Intent: A license and permit bond shall be obtained by any landowner, lessee, person within the city limits
who allows or has reason to know of any vendor or peddler that has obtained permission, either oral or in
writing, from any landowner, lessee, or person to sell, engage in sales, show items for sale to the public;
and it is the intention of this section to cover all peddlers, vendors or solicitors that are not covered by
section 110.01 of this chapter and have not followed the appropriate administrative procedure for license
and bond as set forth in this section.
B. Definitions: The terms "hawker", "peddler", "vendor" or "solicitor", as used in this chapter, do not include a
person who, as part of an association, organization or group, such as a seasonal "farmer's market", sells
agricultural products direct to the consumer, and the sales are not at or from an established business
place. The city shall not be considered a "landowner" for purposes of this chapter.
C. License Tax: For each hawker, peddler or solicitor who operates on private or public property, or goes door
to door, soliciting orders for sale of goods, wares, merchandise, services, insurance or other things of
value, a license tax of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per day or twenty five dollars ($25.00) per week, or fifty
dollars ($50.00) per year shall be payable to the city, as set forth in this section.
D. Landowners And Corporations: Each landowner, lessee, person, partnership and/or corporation which
allows real estate which it owns, leases, controls or has an interest in to be used for sales, of any kind, by
peddlers, vendors or solicitors shall obtain a bond for the protection of the public and the purchaser in the
minimum amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), which shall be filed with the city clerk prior to any
sales being made. In addition, each landowner, lessee, person, partnership and/or corporation shall file
with the city clerk a certified list of employees and/or agents who are conducting sales by name, address,
telephone number and social security number, and the employees and/or agents, whether employees,
agents or mere peddlers, vendors or solicitors, shall be required to pay the license tax in subsection C of
this section for solicitations allowed by landowners, lessees, persons, partnerships and/or corporations,
and shall provide a sales tax permit to the city clerk. (2001 Code § 110.02)
110.03: BUSINESS LICENSE REVIEW BOARD:
A business license review board is established to review and pass upon applications, to issue licenses, and to
hear complaints and determine revocations of licenses under this chapter. The board shall consist of four (4)
members as follows: the chief of police to serve as chairperson, the code enforcement officer, the fire chief
and the city planner. Three (3) members must be present to constitute a quorum. A simple majority vote shall
be required for any action taken by the board. (2001 Code § 110.03)
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 213/395
110.04: LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
No person shall operate, engage in, exercise or pursue any business, profession, trade, occupation or
privilege for which a license tax is levied by this chapter without making application for the license to the
business license review board upon forms provided by the city clerk, paying the required license tax, and
being issued the required license. (2001 Code § 110.04)
110.05: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
A. Time Limit For Review: The business license review board shall review all applications for license under this
chapter within sixty (60) days of receipt of the application.
B. Investigation: The director of public safety or the head of the police department shall conduct an
investigation of each applicant and make a written report of his findings to the business license review
board prior to the board's review of the application.
C. Prohibited Persons: No person shall be issued a license required by this chapter who has been convicted of
any felony or of any crime involving moral turpitude; provided, that in the event a license or permit is
required from a United States government agency or the state of Oklahoma for the proposed business, and
the required license or permit is in fact issued, and is current and in force, the city may not refuse to issue a
license solely on the grounds that the applicant has been convicted of a felony or other crime involving
moral turpitude.
D. Grant Of License: Upon review, the business license review board shall grant the license and direct the city
clerk to issue the same within seven (7) days; provided, that this would be in the best interest of the
citizens of the city and the requirements of this chapter, and that any laws of the city, state or federal
government have been complied with in all respects by the applicant.
E. Term Of License: Annual licenses shall expire on April 30 of each year.
F. Signatures; City Seal: Licenses shall be signed by the mayor and the city clerk, and countersigned by the
city treasurer. The city clerk shall affix the corporate seal of the city to the license. (2001 Code § 110.05)
110.06: LICENSE TO BE DISPLAYED:
Every holder of a license to engage in, exercise or pursue a business, profession, trade, occupation or
privilege shall conspicuously display the license at all times in some part of his place of business or activity
where a person who has entered the place may readily see it, or if he has no particular place of business or
activity, shall carry the license and shall display it to any person who requests to see it. (2001 Code § 110.06)
110.07: TRANSFER OF LICENSE PROHIBITED:
No license issued under this chapter shall be assigned or transferred. (2001 Code § 110.07)
110.08: DUPLICATE LICENSE:
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 214/395
Whenever any license to engage in, exercise or pursue a business, profession, trade, occupation or privilege
has been lost or destroyed without any wrongful act or connivance by the holder, the city clerk, on application,
shall issue a duplicate license for the unexpired time. Before the duplicate is issued, the holder shall make and
file with the city clerk an affidavit that the license has not been transferred, that it has been lost or destroyed
without any wrongful act or connivance by the holder, and that, if believed lost, he has made diligent search for
it and has not been able to find it. The fee for every duplicate license issued, payable to the city clerk, shall be
five dollars ($5.00). (2001 Code § 110.08)
110.09: LICENSE MAY BE REVOKED FOR VIOLATION OF CHAPTER:
Any violation of the provisions of this chapter or the commission of any felony or crime involving moral
turpitude by the licensee, or the violation of any city, state or federal law during the exercise of any business,
profession, trade, occupation or privilege of any license issued under this chapter, shall be grounds for
revocation of the license by the business license review board after notice by certified mail to the licensee at
the address listed upon the application, and upon public hearing by the business license review board. (2001
Code § 110.09)
110.99: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter, or fails to comply
therewith or with any of the requirements thereof, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be
punished by a fine of not more than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), plus court costs. Each day upon which
a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. (2001 Code § 110.99)
Chapter 111
REGULATIONS FOR SPECIFIC BUSINESSES
111.01: REGULATION OF AMUSEMENTS:
No person operating any domino parlor, pool or billiard hall, family amusement center, bowling alley or skating
rink shall permit any person under the influence of liquor or drugs on the premises. The operator shall not
allow any alcohol other than beer or wine, as defined by 37A Oklahoma Statutes section 1-103 of the Alcoholic
Beverage Control Act, to be served or consumed on the premises. (Ord. 1677, 11-5-2018)
111.02: PAWNSHOP REGULATIONS:
A. Definitions:
PAWNBROKER: Owns, operates, manages or works in a pawnshop.
PAWNSHOP: A place of business that receives goods in pledge for a specified period of time, with the
option granted to the customer to redeem or not to redeem the pledged article within the specified period of
time.
B. Register Required: Every pawnbroker shall keep at his place of business a register in which he shall enter
in writing a detailed description of all property taken, purchased or received by him, including any number
that may be in or upon any article, together with the time and name and place of residence of the person
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 215/395
leaving the property, also the amount loaned, the interest charged and the time when the loan falls due,
which registry shall be kept clean and legible. He shall make the entry within one hour after the receipt or
purchase of any property.
1. Every entry shall be made in ink and shall not in any manner be obliterated or erased.
2. To the person negotiating or leaving property, he shall give a plainly written or printed ticket, having upon
it a full and perfect copy of all entries required by ordinance to be kept in the register, for which copy no
charge shall be made.
3. It shall be the further duty of every pawnbroker to make out and deliver to the Director of Public Safety or
head of the Police Department every week, a legible and correct copy from the register of all personal
property or other valuable things received or deposited or purchased during the preceding week,
together with the time when received or purchased and a description of the person or persons by whom
left in pledge or from whom the same was purchased.
4. Provided, that no person shall be required to furnish a description of any property purchased from
manufacturers or wholesale dealers having an established place of business or of goods purchased at
open sale or from any bankrupt stock, or auction sale of estates, or incompetents, or from any other
person having an established place of business. But all goods must be accompanied by a bill of sale or
other evidence of open and legitimate purchase, and must be shown to any officer when demanded.
C. Inspections: The register set forth in subsection B of this section, and any article purchased, taken or
received by a pawnbroker, shall at all times be kept open to the inspection of any law enforcement officer of
the City, County or State.
D. Pledges From Prohibited Persons: No pawnbroker shall purchase, take or receive in pledge, or by gift or on
deposit, or to accept possession of any article of property of or from any person under the influence of
liquor or drugs, or from an incompetent person, or from any person who has previously been convicted of
petty or grand larceny.
E. Stolen Property: No person shall purchase, take or receive or keep in possession of, or dispose of any
stolen property, or to conceal that property, or to fail to promptly inform some law enforcement officer of the
possession thereof, upon circumstances arising calculated to indicate that the property has been stolen or
the possession thereof unlawfully obtained.
F. Dealing With Minors: No pawnbroker shall purchase from or advance money to any person under eighteen
(18) years of age upon anything or articles of value, or have any dealings respecting the title of property in
the possession of any minor, without the written consent of the parent or guardian of the minor.
G. Concealing Lost Goods: No person shall attempt to conceal any lost goods, found or taken by him, or to
efface any marks or brands thereon, or carry the same beyond the limits of the city, or knowingly permit the
same to be done, or to wilfully fail to cause the same to be advertised, sold or otherwise dealt with as
provided by law.
H. Suspicious Circumstances: Any suspicion or circumstance sufficient to put any ordinarily prudent person
upon their guard shall be sufficient notice to any person to whom property shall be offered for a gift, sale or
pledge, to prohibit them from accepting the same; any knowledge, notice or information as to the improper
character of the person offering the same must prevent the sale, gift or pledge from being made until
investigation shall reveal that the same is lawfully made; and no person shall fail to exercise the
precautions herein prescribed, and no person shall accept a gift, sale or pledge of the property prohibited
herein, or which shall be stolen, or shall be in possession of one not entitled thereto, or which shall be
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 216/395
disposed of by one not entitled to, or competent to sell, pledge or give the same away. (2001 Code
§ 111.02)
111.03: JUNK, SECONDHAND AND SALVAGE REGULATIONS:
A. Definitions: For the purposes of this chapter:
JUNK: Is defined and intended to be and include all and every kind of previously used or secondhand
metal, and all other similar articles of whatsoever nature or kind, commonly purchased after primary use
and kept or sold for subsequent use, consumption or traffic, and otherwise ordinarily known as junk.
JUNK DEALER: Owns, operates, manages or works in a junk store.
SECONDHAND AUTOMOBILE PARTS STORE AND JUNK OR SALVAGE YARD: Any business which
deals in automobile salvage and/or the buying and selling of secondhand automobile parts and
accessories.
SECONDHAND AUTOMOBILE PARTS STORE DEALER AND JUNK OR SALVAGE YARD DEALER:
Owns, operates, manages or works in a secondhand automobile parts store and junk salvage yard.
SECONDHAND DEALER: Owns, operates, manages or works in a secondhand store.
SECONDHAND STORE: A place of business that deals primarily in any secondhand or previously used
goods, wares or merchandise.
B. Register Required: Every junk dealer, secondhand dealer, secondhand automobile parts dealer and junk or
salvage yard dealer shall keep at his place of business a register in which he shall enter in writing a
detailed description of all property taken, purchased or received by him, including any number that may be
in or upon any article, together with the time and name and place of residence of the person leaving the
property, also the amount paid or loaned, which registry shall be kept clean and legible. He shall make the
entry within one hour after the receipt or purchase of any property. Every entry shall be made in ink and
shall not in any manner be obliterated or erased.
C. Inspections: The register set forth in subsection B of this section, and property purchased, taken or
received, shall at all times be kept open to the inspection of any law enforcement officer of the city, county
or state.
D. Pledges From Prohibited Persons: No junk dealer, secondhand dealer, secondhand automobile parts dealer
or salvage yard dealer shall purchase, take or receive in pledge, or by gift or on deposit, or to accept
possession of any article of property of or from any person under the influence of liquor or drugs, or from
an incompetent person, or from any person who has previously been convicted of petty or grand larceny.
E. Stolen Property: No junk dealer, secondhand dealer, secondhand automobile parts dealer or salvage yard
dealer shall purchase, take or receive or keep in possession of, or dispose of any stolen property, or
conceal such property, or fail to promptly inform a law enforcement officer of the possession thereof, upon
circumstances arising calculated to indicate that the property has been stolen or the possession thereof
unlawfully obtained.
F. Dealing With Minors: No junk dealer, secondhand dealer, secondhand automobile parts dealer or salvage
yard dealer shall purchase from or advance money to any person under eighteen (18) years of age upon
any thing or articles of value, or have any dealings respecting the title of property in the possession of any
minor, without the written consent of the parent or guardian of the minor.
7/9/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=872 217/395
G. Concealing Lost Goods: No junk dealer, secondhand dealer, secondhand automobile parts dealer or
salvage yard dealer shall attempt to conceal any lost goods found or taken by him, or to efface any marks
or brands thereon, or carry the same beyond the limits of the city, or knowingly permit the same to be done,
or to wilfully fail to cause the same to be advertised sold or otherwise dealt with as provided by law.
H. Suspicious Circumstances: Any suspicion or circumstance sufficient to put any ordinarily prudent person
upon their guard shall be sufficient notice to any person to whom property shall be offered for a gift, sale or
pledge, to prohibit them from accepting the same; any knowledge, notice or information as to the improper
character of the person offering the same must prevent a sale, gift or pledge from being made until
investigation shall reveal that the same is lawfully made; and no person shall fail to exercise the
precautions herein prescribed, and no person shall accept a gift, sale or pledge of the property prohibited
herein, or which shall be stolen, or shall be in possession of one not entitled thereto, or which shall be
disposed of by one not entitled to, or competent to sell, pledge or give the same away. (2001 Code
§ 111.03)
111.04: SELF-SERVICE STATIONS:
A. Definitions:
LIQUIDS: Any flammable and combustible liquid used as motor fuel or otherwise.
SELF-SERVICE STATION: That portion of property where liquids are stored and subsequently dispensed
for sale from fixed approved dispensing equipment by persons other than a service station attendant, and
may include facilities available for sale of other retail products.
B. Attendant Required: A self-service station shall have at least one attendant on duty while the self-service
station is open to the public. The attendant shall be mentally and physically capable of performing the
functions and assuming the responsibilities prescribed to him in this section.
C. Duties Of Attendant; Portable Containers: Any attendant at a self-service station shall supervise, observe
and control the dispensing of any liquids while the liquids are actually being dispensed. He shall prevent
